courses.title: Acroyoga
courses.description: Acroyoga is a practice where the base lifts the flyer into the air to move through a sequence of acrobatic moves. The playful and vigorously physical activity develops trust and communication.\n\nSessions available in NYC: https://learninglab.fans/acroyoga

lessons.title: Warm-up 1: Flashlights
lessons.synopsis: Builds specific strength for hand connection.
lessons.instructions:
1. Present your palms facing forward.
2. Let your hand close a little.
3. Press the two knuckles at the base of the index and middle finger forward.
4. Repeatedly press and relax the two knuckles forward.

Note:---
It's easy to simply open and close the hand and completely miss the point of the exercise. Recall how in yoga pose during downward dog, the inside of the palm often floats up. The exercise is to consciously push the palm down.

Motivation---
The hand-to-hand connection is critical in acroyoga. People often fatigue and let the hand-to-hand connection deteriorate and hurt their partner. This somewhat tedious exercise helps you take better care of your partner.

lessons.title: Warm-up 2: Plank play
lessons.synopsis: Develops ability to hold a shape.
lessons.instructions:
1. Partner A goes into a top of push up position.
2. Partner B takes the ankles of partner A and lifts until partner A's body is horizontal.
3. Partner B will squeeze one ankle and then let's go fo the ankle.
4. Partner A needs to keep the released ankle next to the held ankle.
5. If releasing ankles with a squeeze warning works well, partner B can release ankles without warning.
6. If that works well, partner B can suddenly let go of an ankle and even try to fake out which ankle gets dropped.

Acro Principle---
An acro principle is: "The base balances. The flyer holds the shape."

It means that the base's job is to balance the flyer. And the flyer's job is to hold their shape. Holding the shape means that if the flyer is in hollow body position, the flyer holds that shape.

The reason is that if both the flyer and the base try to balance, an echo chamber of instability is created.

This exercises practices the flyer holding the shape.

Note---
The goal of the exercise is to start gently and ramp up the challenge. It's not nice to overwhelm your partner. As partner B, you want to aim for letting your partner A have some success but also some challenges. The challenges should be so difficult that the foot drops but doesn't painfully hit the ground.

lessons.title: Warm-up 3: Table-on-table
lessons.synopsis: Get sweaty!
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the knees up and lower leg about horizontal.
2. The flyer places their hands a little below the knees. The exact position is that the middle of the base of the palms of the flyer are on the protuberance of the base's tibia (shin bone) - not on the knee cap.
3. The base presents their dominant arm in a nice bone stack.
4. The flyer places their knee on the presented hand.
5. The flyer gently shifts as much weight as possible on the flyer's hands and the knee.
6. The flyer places their knee on the other hand of the base.
7. The flyer should be now on all fours. The base should be like on all fours but flipped on their back.
8. The pair can now "walk", which means that they move opposite arms and knees forward and back.
9. The next challenge is to move both arms and both legs in the same direction. (This will challenge the core.).
10. The biggest challenge is to move arms and legs to the side away from each other.

Bone stacking---
This exercise introduces an important acro concept: bone stacking. A bone stack is if the wrist is directly over the elbow and the elbow directly of the shoulder. If the flyer places weight on such a bone stack, all the weight travels through the bone into the ground. To the base, finding the perfect bone stack should make the flyer feel "weightless". Any other alignment or bent elbows require muscle effort.

The same kind of stacking is also done with the legs: ankle over knee over hip.

Note---
When the flyer wants to place their knees on the base, it is common that a base wants to help by bending their arm. However, then the base is out of bone stack. Instead the base should present the arm in a proper bone stack. And the flyer's job is to reach the position with their knee.

lessons.title: Drill lesson: bird entry
lessons.synopsis: Base learns receiving. Flyer holds shape.
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back and places the arms down along the body.
2. The flyer steps up so that the flyer's toes touch the base's finger tips.
3. The flyer places the middle of the balls of the base's feet on the flyer's bump on the hip bone (ASIS - Anterior Superior Iliac Spine).
4. The flyer leans a tiny little bit forward and then holds the body tight like a plank.
5. The base bends their knees a little bit to allow the flyer to come forward and then pushes the flyer back to the starting position.
6. The base repeats this, each time receiving the flyer deeper until the maximum depth is reached. (Some flexible bases can get their knees all the way to the ground!)

Important---
A common tendency is that people want to push right away to go up to bird. However, I've found over and over that skipping over this exercises causes people to progress slower.

Usually, they ran into a pose that they can't muscle. And then they are stuck hard because now they have to learn technique in a difficult pose.

I recommend staying with this exercise. The flyer should have learned to allow the base to control the movement without any trying to help. (Trusting and letting go of control can be very hard for people. Learning this here, will make everything so much easier.) The base should have learned to control the flyer's movement with precision and control. (Target precise end positions for the movement. Learn to gently accelerate and decelerate.)

Tip---
Some beginning bases struggle with hamstring flexibility. Rolling up a yoga mat and putting it under the sacrum can help.

Common Mistakes---
- The flyer pushes their hips forward to follow the base's feet but leans back to keep their weight on their feet.
- The flyer pulls back to help coming up.
- The base let's the flyer drop forward to quickly and freaks out the flyer.
- The base pushes the flyer too far at the end and causes the flyer to fall backwards.

lessons.title: Position lesson 1: bird
lessons.synopsis: Quintessential pose that everyone starts with.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in the lowest position from the previous bird receiving exercise.
2. The base presents the palms in a nice bone stack with the finger tips pointing out.
3. When the flyers hands naturally reach the base's hands without reaching, the flyer places the hands on top with the finger tips facing forward.
4. As the base bent their knees, there should have been a point where it feels like the flyers weight has shifted over the base.
5. When the point has passed, the base should try to scoop up the flyer with their heels and press the flyer into the air.
6. The end position is that the flyer and base both have their arms and legs in vertical bone stacks. The flyer arches back (like upward dog in yoga) to accommodate the straight arms.

Common Problems---
- The base has tight hamstrings. A pillow or rolled up mat under the sacrum can help short-term, but flexibility needs to be developed.
- The flyer and/or base bent their elbows/knees and are out of stack. Feedback from the spotter helps.
- The base doesn't know how to balance the flyer. Some bases are truly disoriented and don't realize that when the flyer drifts left, they have to push right. Some bases do not flatten their back against the ground. The rounded back doesn't allow them to ground in to the floor.

Spotting---
The best choice for the beginning spotter is to stand next to the flyer's hips (center of gravity). The spotter should be in a goddess stance: feet wide and knees bent. This will allow them to have good body ergonomics to deal with the weight of the flyer and allows them to be close. One arm should be under the thighs of the flyer and the other arm under the belly. The spotter should not touch the flyer until needed to avoid disrupting the balance.

A common mistake is that the spotter will be too far away or too gingerly to actually do anything in the moment of need.

Deeper Cuts (Ways To Challenge Yourselves)---
- Leg presses: The base bends and extends their arms and legs as low as possible.
- Swivels: The base twists their feet left and right to make the flyer swivel left and right.
- The base takes a foot away. (Flyers usually imagine that they have to lean or contort. However, they have to keep their shape very tight instead.)
- Taking hands away: The base should press the ball's of their feet to the sky until the weight goes out of the hand connection. (Think stepping on the gas pedal of a car.)

lessons.title: Position lesson 2: king throne
lessons.synopsis: The other easy pose for novices.
lessons.instructions:
1. The flyer steps with their feet next to the ears of the base and faces away.
2. The base grabs the flyer's ankles.
3. The base aims their feet for the flyer's 'thutt' (the area where the thighs and the butt meet).
4. The flyer leans back to transfer weight on the the base's feet.
5. The base straightens their legs and arms until they are in a nice bone stack.
6. The base transfers their hands to hold the flyer's feet from the bottom in a C-grip (like a lego person).

Tips---
- If the flexibility and size differences make it hard for the base to get their feet low enough under the butt of the flyer, there are two things to try. One, the flyer can grab the base's feet and push them down. Two, the flyer can step on the chest of the base.
- The flyer doesn't lean back and thus the base can't lift the flyer.

Spotting---
The spotter should be partially behind and to the side of the flyer. The goal is to have the spotter's body behind the flyer to block the flyer from falling backwards. At the same time, the spotter should see the face of the base because any grimaces can be a sign of trouble. The hand of the spotter should be hovering next to the thighs of the flyer.

Deeper Cuts---The deeper cuts for the bird pose can also be done for the king throne pose.

Note---
There are two very similar throne poses. When I learned it, one was called king throne (this one) and the other one straddle throne. Different groups use different names. Chair is also a commonly used name.

lessons.title: Position lesson 3: high-flying whale
lessons.synopsis: An relaxing pose that's easy to share with friends.
lessons.instructions:
1. The flyer stands with their feet next to the base's ears, facing away.
2. The base garbs the ankles of the flyer.
3. The base aims their toes for roughly the bra strap or heart rate monitor height on the flyer's back.
4. The flyer leans back.
5. As the base receives the flyer, the base extends their arms.
6. The end position should be roughly with the arms and legs leaning away from each other to equal parts. This is a counter balance, think of how some bridges are built with beams equally facing away from each other.
7. The base should offer the flyer to adjust the stretch in the flyer's back by pushing more or less with the base's toes.

Spotting---
The spotter should be in a goddess stance with their arms under the flyer's back and hamstrings.

A Little Back Anatomy---
The back has a spine in the middle. The base should avoid the spine.

The upper part of the back is made up of the chest and ribs. That's a good place to put the base's feet. Lower on the back a soft area starts. Especially the area near the meeting point of the ribs and soft area should be avoided because that's where the kidneys are.

Solar vs. Lunar Acroyoga---
Acroyoga has two main branches. The solar branch is energetic and circus like. Those are the poses that we've been doing until now. The lunar branch is relaxing, healing, and restorative. These were poses where the flyers gets to relax instead of climb around. High-flying whale is one of such poses. It can feel very relaxing for the flyer to stay in the pose for a few minutes.

Deeper Cuts---
- In high-flying whale pose, the base can place the flyer's feet on the base's knees. Then the base can hold onto the top of the knees of the flyer. Now, the flyer can bend their knees to allow the flyer to 'fall back', but keep the flyer from actually falling with the hold onto the flyer's knees.

- A fun way to exit is for the flyer to reach their arms back and the base to place the flyer's hands on the ground. This requires both enough back stretch from the flyer and enough flexibility from the base. From here, the flyer can go into a handstand and land on their feet.

Note---
In case you are curious, there is such a thing as low-flying whale!

lessons.title: Flow: bird, king throne, whale
lessons.synopsis: Putting all the poses together into a flow.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in bird.
2. The base takes a foot off.
3. The flyer brings the free leg to the chest.
4. The base places the free foot on the flyer's 'thutt.'
5. The flyer places the foot of the bent leg onto the base's shin.
6. The flyer and base repeat the process with the other side.
7. The base bends the knees to allow the flyer's hips to lower below the flyer's shoulders.
8. The flyer sits up in king throne.
9. The base grips the flyer's feet with a C-grip (lego person grip.)
10. The base takes a foot off.
11. The base rotates the foot to be across the sacrum of the base.
12. The base slowly lowers the leg with the flyer on. At the same time, the other leg glides up the back of the flyer. The flyer slowly leans back.
12. The coordination of legs and flyer ends up in high-flying whale.
13. The base rotates the foot on the back to be parallel to the spine again and places the other foot on the upper back of the flyer.
14. Do everything backwards to end up in bird.

Communication---
The transitions of the flow require developing clear communication. Saying, 'move your left foot.' Is confusing because it's unclear if left is from the perspective of the base and flyer. Also, people can easily get confused and say 'left' but mean 'right.'

A clear way to communicate is to announce what you want to do, e.g. 'keep your wait here' or 'lift this butt.' The verbal cue is followed by a hand squeeze.

Spotting---
Spotting is a carefully orchestrated dance. The spotter has to often move around. As a rule of thumb, spotting from behind the back is often a good idea. The back tends to be what's vulnerable to the flyer because people have arms and legs that can brace falls to the front. Also, being at the back, the spotter is out of the way of the flyer.

Tip---
Most people rush a bit through learning the poses. They'll have minimally learned one pose and move on. Doing the transitions of the flow requires being able to take a foot way. If you are struggling with the flow, go back to each pose and practice what's in the section for 'deeper cuts.'

Parallel vs Perpendicular Foot---
In the description of the transition from throne to whale, the base should turn their foot perpendicular across the back. However, some teachers teach a foot parallel to the spine.

Having the foot across the back is nicer to the flyer. If the foot is only on one side of the spine, the flyer has to stabilize that.

It's good to start by being nice to your flyer. If you later find that your flyer doesn't need the help and you want to move faster, feel free to use a parallel foot.

lessons.title: Warm-up 1: Partner leg throw downs
lessons.synopsis: Develop balance skills for bases
lessons.instructions:
1. Partner A lies on their back with their legs straight up. (A ninety-degree angle at the hips.)
2. Partner B throws the feet of partner A left and right. Start easy and then get more intense and unpredictable.
3. Switch it up by pulling and pushing on the feet. Partner A should hold a strong ninety-degree angle at the hips, which should cause their hips and respectively torso to lift up.

Variation:---
- Start with partner A’s arms wide to have more leverage.
- Progress to partner A’s arms alongside the body for more challenge.

Motivation:---
Develops balance skills for basing.

Tips:---
- HUG THE SHOULDERS TO THE GROUND: Most people have a bit of a rounded back. You may picture the round keel of a boat. As soon as it's put on dry land, it rolls on its side. Construction cranes on the other hand extend legs out of the side to have a wider base. Similarly, if the person on the ground focused on extending the outside edges of the shoulder blade to the ground, they will have a wider base.

- YIELDING: Initially, the person on the ground is best served by keeping as rigid as possible. However, once the tossing partner generates overwhelming tosses, yielding just enough to keep the upper back "glued" to the ground is more helpful. In physics terms, the side that one is tossed towards becomes the fulcrum. The legs become the weight. The more counterweight one can generate leaning opposite to the legs helps. Leaving the opposite shoulder on the ground is more counterweight than allowing it to be lifted up.

Deeper cuts:---
- Alternate light and strong tosses: This trains the partner on the ground sensitivity.
- Vary the speed of the toss: For example, start lightly tossing and finish with a fling.

Common mistake:---
When pulling on the lying partner’s legs, the torso should lift up. However, often the partner allows the ninety-degree angle at the hips to collapse and then lifts up their head to pretend to do the shape. Remind them to tighten the angle at their hips.

lessons.title: Warm-up 2: Counterbalance sitting down
lessons.synopsis: Trains partner-coordinated weight shifting
lessons.instructions:
1. Both partners face each other standing.
2. They connect opposite hands in bro grip. (Grabbing the opposite wrist.)
3. Both partners lean away from each other and extend their arms.
4. Both partners slowly sit down until they hover over the ground.
5. Both partners stand back up.
6. Switch hands and repeat.

Motivation:---
Trains counterbalance and gradual weight-shifts coordinated with the partner.

Deeper cuts:---
The closer the feet are together, the more challenging the exercise becomes.

Common mistake:---
People are often afraid to trust their partner. Thus, they keep their body weight over their own feet and defeat the purpose of the exercise. Moving the feet closer together and fully extending the arms prevents this kind of "cheating."

lessons.title: Warm-up 3: Push-up partner clapping - opposite leg raise
lessons.synopsis: Trains tightness for the flyer
lessons.instructions:
1. Both partners face each other in plank pose (top of push-up).
2. They lift opposite hands and clap.
3. Keep switching the hands that clap.

Motivation:---
Develops body tension for flyers. It’s also excellent to warm up the body.

Deeper cuts:---
Lift the leg opposite to the lifted hand. (Thus one is balancing on one hand and one foot in plank pose.)

lessons.title: Drill lesson: bird practice: no hands, one foot, leg ups, rotations
lessons.synopsis: Develops balance skills for transitions
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in bird pose.
2. The base presses the ball’s of their feet up (like accelerating in a car) until there is no more weight in the hands. Then the flyer can release the hands. Reconnect hands.
3. The base removes one foot.
4. The base bends and straightens their legs like a push-up but with their legs - a leg up.
5. The base pivots the flyer left and right.

Motivation:---
Develop range of motion for the base to move the flyer into and out of different positions. The more the base can support the flyer away from a perfect bone stack, the easier the next lessons will become.

Communication:---
Remember to communicate with hand squeezes which leg keeps the weight and which leg moves. Words like left and right are confusing because it’s unclear who’s left it is. Make sure to say what the squeeze means.

Tips:---
- Bases often drop the flyer when they remove one leg. The flyer tends to fall towards the side of the remaining leg. The physical effect is similar to stepping up onto the side of a sailboat. That side will dip down because the side is away from the center of gravity. To correct that, the base has to move their leg to the center of their body. Learning to receive the flyer’s weight by centering the base leg over their own body is a critical skill for the rest of this level.

Spotting:---
The spotter should stand on the side with one arm under the belly and one arm under the thighs of the flyer. The spotter should maintain eye contact with the base’s face. The base making a face is often a warning signal that a crash is imminent.

lessons.title: Position lesson 1: Shoulderstand
lessons.synopsis: Enter the exciting world of inversions
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the knees bent.
2. The flyer stands over the base’s belly facing the base’s head.
3. The flyer bends forward and reaches between their legs to place their hands on the middle of the base’s thighs in a C-grip (Lego person grip).
4. The base places their hands on the flyer’s shoulders. (See discussion below.)
5. The flyer steps onto the base’s knees.
6. The flyer lifts one leg up and as far over towards the base’s head as possible.
7. The flyer might have to make a hop to reach shoulderstand.

Tips:---
- HAND POSITION ON SHOULDERS: Most bases have the inclination to put their hands _under_ the flyer’s shoulder. That’s bad. It creates pressure on their own wrist and doesn’t support the flyer in the best way. The base’s hands should rather be on the back of the shoulder plates. The cue is to think of the hands more as suction cups molding to the shoulder blade.

- BASES SHOULD MAINTAIN PRESSURE TOWARDS THEIR THIGHS: The flyer’s and base’s arm create a triangle over the ground. Flyers can push the base’s hands back, which in turn causes the flyer’s hands to lift off the base’s thighs. When that happens the triangle is broken and the pose crashes. Thus, the base should maintain a constant downward pressure towards their thighs to keep this from happening. (And flyers should be conscious that their goal is to go up, not forward!)

- FLYER’S STAGGING LEGS: Some flyers have a hard time getting their hips over their shoulders. Staging the legs tends to solve that. Staging means that while one foot of the flyer remains on the base’s knee, the other flyer foot reaches over as far as possible to create a counterweight.

Entry from bird:---
Once this is working well, it’s time to attempt entering shoulder stand from bird.

1. The pair starts in bird.
2. The flyer holds the base’s ankles in C-grip.
3. The base tilts their toes down to tilt the flyer's shoulders towards the base's hands.
4. Once the flyer’s shoulders are on the base’s hands, the flyer can push their hips of the base’s feet to enter shoulder stand.

Common mistake:---
Some flyer struggle to get their hips of the feet of the base. A simple exercise teaches them what they need to do: The flyers stands and hold their straight arms down at a 45-degree angle. A partner puts their hands on top of the flyer’s hand. The flyer is asked to push their straight arms up as hard as they can. That’s the same motion that they need to do to lift their hips off.

Spotting:---
The spotter should have their hands on both sides of the flyer’s hips. The main risk is that the flyer falls towards their back. The spotter should push the hips back so that the flyer lands on the base’s feet in case of going over.

Deeper cuts:---
- FLYER RANGE OF MOTION: Once the flyer is in shoulder stand, they can move their legs through different positions to develop range of motion for both the flyer and the base: Legs straight up, front split, side split, tucked.

- SLOW DESCEND: An excellent exercise is for the flyer to very slowly descend from shoulder stand back to the ground. The slowing down is achieved by a counterbalance. As the flyer’s feet move towards the ground, their weight should be counteracted by pushing the hips further back. This skill can be built to the point where the flyer barely hovers over the ground and can push back up into shoulderstand without touching down.

lessons.title: Position lesson 2: Shin-to-foot
lessons.synopsis: A new kind of challenge
lessons.instructions:
1. The pair starts in bird.
2. The base removes one foot.
3. The flyer brings the free knee to their chest (like going to throne).
4. The base places their free foot on the shin of the flyer’s free shin. (See foot position description below)
5. The flyer shifts onto the shin and repeats with the other leg.
6. At first, the flyer stays in child’s pose on the base’s feet. (Let things stabilize before moving on.)
7. When comfortable, the flyer can go to a _high_ kneeling pose. (Important: When sitting up, shift the hips forward. If only sitting up low, the flyer will fall off the base’s feet!)
8. When ready to come down, go back to child’s pose.
9. Connect hands.
10. The base moves the flyer towards their feet while the flyer extends their knees to stand up.

Base’s foot position:---
The shin bone (tibia) has a bump (protrusion) near the knee. The middle of the ball’s of the feet of the flyer should be on the bump.

Be close to the flyer’s knee but void the knee itself.

For the base’s heel placement, find a post that is comfortable to the flyer. Some flyer’s feel pain when the base’s heel goes across their shinbone.

How to develop comfort and stability:---
Some students dislike standing on the base. It feels unstable and shaky. Here is the reason of why it feels shaky and how to overcome it.

Most people can stand on the ground just fine and are very comfortable. Why does it get so shaky when standing on top of a partner? Well, when we get scared, we tense up and react to every little thing out of proportion. Recall walking on slick ice. Now if the flyer does a quick reaction, it freaks out the base. So the base does a quick reaction. That freaks out the flyer. The result is an echo chamber of jitters.

The solution that the nervous systems have to get used to that things are actually very stable. And if the partner does a small twitch, they don’t have to react with a panic twitch. Doing that is pretty simple. Simply have the flyer hang out in child’s pose for a minute or longer. The nervous systems will calm down. Everything will become more stable. Having the flyer dance with the arms in the air is another good exercise. The flyer will be distracted from being tight and scared in order to discover that there is a lot more safe range of motion possible than they thought.

Spotting:---
The spotter should start by having one hand in C-grip near the flyer’s bicep. This can catch the flyer falling forward. The spotter’s other arm should be around the flyer’s hip. As the flyer comes up on their knees, the spotter transitions to having both arms around the hip.

Tips:---
- The flyer should pull their knees slightly together because there is a tendency for the flyer to push the base’s legs apart.
- The base’s perfect stack is NOT with the legs straight up. The base’s legs should aim towards the hips of the flyer. The base’s legs and the flyer’s thighs should make a straight line. Because the flyer is often larger than the flyer, that line is angled in a bit.

lessons.title: Position lesson 3: Foot-to-shin
lessons.synopsis: This pose is the entryway to slacro
lessons.instructions:
1. The pair starts in king throne.
2. The flyer places their feet on the base’s shin. (The same foot placement as shin-to-foot only on the base.)
3. The flyer slowly stands up while the base moves their feet down so that the base can provide a horizontal shelf with their shins.
4. Coming out of it is doing the steps in reverse.

Common problem:---
The process of coming out of the pose requires that the flyer sit down while the base straightens their legs. The flyers are often to reluctant to sit down too far without feeling the base’s feet. Yet because raising the base’s feet also raises the angle of the shins that they are standing on, they risk slipping off. Finding the point of the flyer reaching the point where they sit low enough without slipping off can be scary for the flyer. The flyer will likely need some reassurance of how far away the base’s feet are: "3 inches, 2 inches, 1 inch, almost there!"

Direct entry:---
Once entering from throne works well, we want to enter foot-to-shin directly from standing. The skill to balance this pose on one foot will be critical for the integration flow.

1. The base lies on their back with their knees tugged onto the chest and their shins as horizontal as possible.
2. The flyer stands next to the hip of the base.
3. The flyer places the inside foot onto the opposite shin of the base.
4. The flyer pours weight into the foot very gradually. (Going too fast will cause the base to roll to the side. The base has to hug the leg towards the center line.)
5. Once the flyer has all their weight on the base, they drag their free foot up along the base’s side. (The dragging adds stability.)
6. The flyer can place the second foot on the base’s shin.
7. When the pair is comfortable, the base can slowly move their knees above their hips.
8. Exit by doing the steps backwards.

Spotting:---
The spotter should stand on the side of the flyer and put their straight arms in front of and behind the flyer. The spotter should bear hug the flyer in case of a fall.

Safety Tip:---
This pose can come down very quickly. The spotter should be very prepared to grab the flyer quickly without notice.

The biggest danger is that if the flyer’s foot slips to the inside. If the flyer’s foot slips straight down, the flyer usually lands on their feet. However, if the foot slips towards the inside, the legs can fly very quickly to the side and rotate the flyer to come down on their side. Take your time to slowly graduate this. There is no shame in spending time to slowly pour the weight onto the base and to simply repeat that without actually going up.

lessons.title: Machine: bird, shoulder stand, shin-to-foot, foot-to-shin, king throne
lessons.synopsis: Putting all the poses together into a flow.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in bird. (See the previous level)
2. Go to shoulder stand. (See the earlier lesson)
3. The flyer bends their knees and brings their knees towards the base’s feet.
4. The flyer transfers their hands to the base’s wrists.
5. If the base can lower their feet enough, the flyer can now sit up in shin-to-foot.
6. The flyer may help by wiggling their hands onto the base’s palms. Then the flyer can push their chest over their own knees.
7. Once in shin-to-foot, the flyer transfers all weight to one leg.
8. The flyer brings the free foot to the base’s shin.
9. The flyer does the same with the other leg and is now in foot-to-shin.
10. Use any exit from here, e.g. go to king throne.

Tips:---
- Getting the hips over the legs to enter shin-to-foot can be difficult. Wide legs (flyer and base) can help lower the flyer’s hips more.

- A lot of the transitions require balance. People expecting to succeed on the first try and right away set themselves up for frustration. Take your time to develop balance. Spend time simply hanging out to allow the wobbles to work themselves out. Use hands and gliding along the partner’s body for added stability.

Spotting:---
Spotting is often a dance. Spotting this flow requires moving to different spotting positions. When the flyer is leaning forward, have a C-grip in front of their bicep to catch them from falling forward. When they are standing, put the flyer into a "cage" between your outreached arms to catch them with a bear hug if needed. Most other times, having the spotters’ hands next to the flyer’s hips is the most effective.

Generally maintain a position where you can see the base’s face for early warning about impending trouble. Try to stay towards the flyer’s back to be out of their way.

lessons.title: Warm-up 1: Straddle pike pulses
lessons.synopsis: Strengthens straddle pike for flyers.
lessons.instructions:
1. Sit on the floor with your legs spread wide and straight.
2. Place the finger tips of your hands in front of you in between your legs.
3. Push the fingertips against the ground and lift the legs in short pulses.


Motivation---
This exercise is a bit like Popeye eating spinach - a bit unpleasant but very important. Flyers often need to hold straddle pike (see below) for extended periods. Further, the better they can hold straddle pike, the easier it’ll be to achieve the poses. This exercise develops the muscles for a strong straddle pike.


Vocabulary---
Starting with this level a bit of acrobatics vocabulary will become important. Vocabulary allows fast and precise communication.

- Straddle: Spread legs.
- Pike: Bend ninety degrees at the hips.
- Straddle pike: Spread legs and bend ninety degrees at the hips.

Tip: Practice with a partner. One person calls out the position. The other person assumes it. You want to practice this so that when the base calls out desperately “straddle pike” because a crash is imminent, you know what you need to do.

lessons.title: Warm-up 2: Counterbalance Partner Foot Hold
lessons.synopsis: Develops matching weight transfer between the base and the flyer.
lessons.instructions:
1. The base and flyer stand side-by-side.
2. The base places the right foot inside of the right foot of the flyer (directly touching).
3. (There are variously elegant ways of starting this.) The base takes and lifts up the left foot of the flyer with both hands. The flyer will stand on the right foot.
4. Important: The flyer keeps both legs locked and straight. The flyer’s left foot is flexed hard.
5. As of now, the flyer is probably still balanced on the right foot. The flyer will start leaning out to the right while the base holds onto the flyer’s left foot with both hands.
6. As the flyer increasingly leans to the right, the base will have to lean to the left to keep holding onto the flyer’s foot.
7. The final position is that the flyer is leaning perhaps horizontally to the right. The base holds onto the flyer’s flex foot with one hand and the other hand is on the flyer’s calf to stabilize swinging.


Motivation---
This exercise practices counterbalance. The flyer and base learn how to transfer weight to each other and match the weight transfer of their partner.


Common issues---
- The flyer is often afraid to lean out and keeps all their weight on their own leg. The flyer needs to be encouraged to lean out.

- “Swinging like a barndoor” is another common issue. That means as the base holds the flyer's foot, the flyer’s head becomes a very distant point. The distant point can have a tendency to very quickly and instantly swing like a big barn door. There isn’t an easy fix. Some things come very quickly out of balance, and one has to learn to keep them in balance.

- The flyer’s foot on the ground could slip. However, if the base follows the instructions and places their foot directly on the inside of the flyer’s foot that should block any slippage.


Deeper cuts---
- A nice touch is when the flyer reaches their arms overhead and turns their torso to face the sky. It looks pretty.

- With more skill, the flyer can lean out farther and farther until the flyer can almost lie down on the ground. The flyer may start on the floor and the base pulls them off the floor.

lessons.title: Warm-up 3: Sit-up partner pike
lessons.synopsis: Develops coordination between the base and the flyer.
lessons.instructions:
1. One person lies on the back on the floor. Their feet should point straight up. Their arms are also raised straight up above the shoulder.
2. The second person grabs the first person’s ankles and places their own ankles on top of the first person’s feet. (Both people should look like they are in the top of a push-up position. Only the first person is on their back and the second person on top of the first person.)
3. Both people will coordinate the next movement. Partner A will sit up and raise their hands overhead. Partner B will pike and end up in a handstand with their hip bent at a ninety-degree angle. (Both people should have the same body position, albeit inverted towards each other.)


Motivation---
This is a great physical exercise that warms up the body well. Plus, it practices coordination between two people.


Safety---
There is a chance that the person on top will go forward. With their hands holding the partner’s ankles, they may not be able to braise their head forward tumble. Thus, it’s a good idea to have a spotter for the first time at the shoulders of partner B. Once people understand their body motions, they tend to be pretty confident on doing the exercise on their own.


Tips---
- The base basically does a situp. If the flyer doesn’t help, the flyer can pin down the base. A lot of the move is driven by the flyer actively pulling their hips over their shoulders.

- The base needs to be mindful of how much their are pushing the flyer forward or back. The base wants to be careful to keep the flyer’s shoulders over the flyer’s hands. If they are of different height, the base will have to accommodate the difference.

lessons.title: Drill lesson: Practice half-moon alignment for side star
lessons.synopsis: Preparation for learning side star.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start by standing with your feet together.
2. Rotate your left foot out by ninety degrees. Your feet should form a T.
3. Bend forward over your left foot. Your torso and right leg should create a perfectly horizontal line.
4. Rotate your right hip back until your right hip is perfectly on top of your left hip.
5. Try with the other side.


Verify the following alignment:---
1. Your left foot should point forward (not to the side).
2. Your right leg should be perfectly horizontal.
3. Your hips should be perfectly stacked on top of each other.
4. Ensure no arch in the back.


Motivation---
Side star is a pose that many students only learn over multiple sessions. A major struggle is getting the alignment right. This exercise allows you to focus on getting the alignment right before you start bouncing and flailing around on top of someone else.

Half moon in yoga is pretty similar to side star in acroyoga. However, there are differences on how people do the two. These instructions may not be what your branch of yoga does but what is needed for acroyoga.


Tip---
- To get the right alignment, imagine two walls closing in towards you and pressing you flat. You are looking to fit into a shape that is very flat.

- If balance is hard, feel free to hold onto the wall or a chair.

lessons.title: Position lesson 1: Paserita twist
lessons.synopsis: A challenging and very useful transition.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in bird.
2. The flyer folds forward and assumes straddle pike. This is called Folded Leaf.
3. The base guides the flyer’s hand to hold the opposite ankle. The flyer will maintain this twisted position, providing a solid block for the base to maneuver.
4. The base brings the flyer onto one foot so that the other foot becomes free. (See below for different strategies.)
5. The base places the free foot in front of the other foot like third position in ballet (toes pointing out in opposite directions). The freet foot should slide in between the existing base foot and the flyer’s hips.
6. The base removes the previous foot and finishes rotating the flyer 180 degrees.
7. The base offers the newly free foot on the side of the hips of the flyer.
8. The flyer places the top of their thigh on the free foot from the base.
9. The flyer ends up in Straddle Bat. The pose is essentially like Folded Leaf, but rotated 180 degrees.


Challenges---
The following challenges happen almost always when students learn this process:

1. Initially, the base can’t take a foot away because the flyer’s weight is on both feet. See below for a deeper discussion.

2. If the base gets the flyer on one foot, the base drops the flyer towards that side. Essentially, the base is similar to a sailboat. Because the keel is round, if you place all the weight on one side, the sailboat tilts that way. The remedy is that when a base takes the flyer on one foot, the base has to bring the supporting foot to their center. If they keep the foot on the side of their body, they are going to roll into that direction.

3. If all the above is successful, virtual all new flyers will straighten their hips. Without offering the base a shelf (the thigh as a shelf), the base has nothing to push them up with. And the flyer falls down. The remedy is to repeat to the flyer that maintaining straddle bat throughout the maneuver is critical. Even emphasizing this, the flyer will likely not do it, but at least, they’ll be more responsive when they are asked to resume straddle bat.


How to bring the flyer onto one foot---
There are three main strategies to bring the flyer onto one foot of the base. They are discussed here with their pros and cons.

1. The most common way this is taught is that the base pushes the back of the flyer up. The base’s hands will be over the base’s shoulders. The flyer twists so that their chest opens up to the ceiling and their free arm twists opposite. The twisting motion will spiral the flyer onto one foot.

Con: The flyer has to be flexible, can’t have a big belly, and has to be fairly spatially aware to support this move. I’ve found a lot of first time flyers struggle to provide that support.

2. The most straightforward way is that the base places their hands under the flyer’s shoulders and props up the flyer’s torso.

Con: The base needs to be fairly strong to pull this off because the flyer is above the belly of the base. And that’s anatomically not a strong position for the base to push up on.

3. The most feasible way given flyer and base limitations are to tilt the flyer in the opposite direction of the base’s target foot. Picture the base’s target foot being the right foot. The base would push the upper chest of the base to the left until the base’s left foot is free. Because the arm’s aren’t strong in this position, the base can smartly bend the knees and use the knees to lever the flyer to the side.


Tip---
As you notice from the length of the discussions of challenges with this short move, there might be a lot to figure out. If you try to muscle through or try to do it all at once on the first try, it’s likely going to be a mangle that’s hard to troubleshoot. However, you can go very slowly and step by step.

1. Shift the flyer onto one base foot.
2. If the flyer falls out, the base didn’t center the foot well.
3. Remind the flyer to go back to straddle pike because they likely went out of it.
4. You are almost home now. Offer the free foot for the flyer to put their thigh on.

A spotter can also provide a very hands-on spot so that the base and flyer can get a feel for the general direction of everything.


Spotting---
1. The spotter starts with the usual bird spotting: One arm under the belly and one under the thighs of the flyer. The spotter should maintain goddess stance.

2. As the flyer goes to Folded Leaf, the spotter walks around to be behind the back of the flyer. The spotter’s hands should be under the flyer’s thighs near the hip.

3. As the flyer is rotated to Straddle Bat, the spotter should follow maintaining behind the flyer’s back and hands under the flyer’s thighs near the hip.

lessons.title: Position lesson 2: Straddle bat
lessons.synopsis: One of the key poses for many transitions.
lessons.instructions:
Straddle Bat is the pose that the last move ended in. So this isn’t a new pose. However, because it’s so central, it should be its own lesson that people can find. Getting into it through paserita twist is one option. This lesson gives two other options.

The pose itself has the flyer in straddle bat. They are hanging from the top of their thighs near the hip. The flyer’s torso is in between the base’s legs. The flyer faces towards the head of the base.


Option 1: Entering Straddle Bat Directly---
1. The base has their feet up and stacked. The flyer is standing below the base and faces away from the base.
2. The flyer places their hands on the feet of the base to prepare to hang from the feet.
3. The flyer leans back between the base’s legs and hangs from the base’s feet by the arms.
4. The goal of the flyer is to lever their thighs onto the base’s feet. This is easiest accomplished by first balling up into a ball by tucking the knees to the chest.
5. Once the flyer is in a ball, the flyer can relatively easily shoot the legs up towards the sky.
6. There might be some shuffling needed to get perfectly into straddle bat. The flyer can be very hands-on. The base can help by pushing the flyer up by the shoulders.


Option 2: Entering Straddle Bat Through Back Flying---
1. Begin with back flying. Back flying will be taught later. It’s essentially like bird but the flyer is flipped around and the base’s feet are on the flyer’s butt. To enter back flying, the flyer stands facing away from the base. The base’s feet are on the flyer’s butt. The flyer and base connect hands. The flyer hops back onto the base’s feet.

2. Going from back flying to straddle bat requires careful coordination between the flyer’s and base’s motion. The base slips their feet from the flyer’s butt to the side of the hips to end up in the straddle bat position. The base can hold the flyer in back flying well with the feet on the back. However, once the base’s feet slip to the side of the flyer’s hips, the flyer would fall through. The flyer has to enter straddle pike early enough to prevent a fall.


Spotting---
Entering directly is best spotting by the spotter putting a hand under the flyer’s shoulder.

Entering through back flying is also well spotted by teh spotter putting a hand under the flyer’s shoulder. However, at certain times like near the end position, having the spotter be under the thighs near the hip is going to be better.

lessons.title: Position lesson 3: Side star
lessons.synopsis: Learning side star is a major step in the progression of very acroyoga journey.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in straddle bat.
2. The base offers the arms straight up from the shoulder. The flyer connects hands (two fingers on the wrist and two fingers wrapped - see below).
3. The flyer pushes on the base’s arms. The goal of the flyer is to pivot around the left foot of the base so that the flyer’s torso lifts up to horizontal.
4. The flyer should end up in side star.


Alternative entry---
1. The flyer stands at the level of the base’s hip on the side of the base.
2. The flyer’s foot points towards the base’s hip.
3. The flyer assumes the side star position while maintaining their weight on their own.
4. The flyer should place their hand roughly on the inside of the base’s leg near the knee. The flyer’s arm should be straight.
5. The base places the closest foot on the flyter’s hip bone as close as possible to the crook.
6. The flyer should NOT try to put weight on the base but simply shift their weight towards the other side of the base.
7. When the base feels like the weight of the flyer is on the base’s leg, the base should push the flyer up and straighten the foot.


Discussion: Entering side star from the ground or from straddle bat---
Traditionally, side star is taught by entering from the floor. To many people it seems simpler because they are starting from the ground. However, there is a major difficulty that often occupies beginners fruitlessly for a very long time. The flyer tries to put their weight on the base down. The base tries to lift the flyer up. That opposite down and up movement tends to destabilize the two. (If you followed the instructions, the flyer doesn’t put the weight down but across.)

Entering side star from straddle bat challenges the flyer to visualize how their body is supposed to rotate from facing down to facing the side. However, all the movements, the base and flyer work in the same direction. Thus aside from the conceptual challenges, the movement is more straight forward.


Types of side stars---
If you pay keen attention, the two side stars above are actually different side stars. With one the head of the flyer faces away from the base and the other one across the base. If you take it mathematically, there are eight different side stars possible.

- Inside vs. outside side star: The head of the flyer indicates if its an inside or outside side star. If the head faces away from the base, it’s an outside side star. If the head faces across the base, it’s an inside side star.

- Regular vs. reverse side star: The face of the flyer can face towards the head of the base (regular side star) or away (reverse side star).

- Left vs right foot of the base: Self explanatory.

Thus, one could have a reverse outside side star on the left foot of the base. You can use the above to decipher what that means.


Spotting---
The main concern for spotting side star is that the flyer could tilt towards their head and fall onto it. Typically, the spotter has their hands on both side of the flyer’s hips. The spotter usually stays on the back of the flyer. Flyers often rotate in side star as well as continue with rotations into other directions. The spotter follows behind the back of the flyer. Spotting is often a dance where the spotter has to keep moving around.


Perspective---
Learning side star is hard compared to the other poses that we have learned so far. The other poses are relatively easy. Some students will get it on the first try. Other students will get it after three or so tries. However, side star can often take multiple sessions. It requires a lot of balance for the flyer and the base.

Side star is a key pose that will provide essential for many machines to come. Bird, throne, side star, and star are frequent elements of machines. You want to develop good skill in these poses. Particularly, you want to practice range of motion exercises that’ll help you in the future with transitions into and out of them.

And, no! You can’t simply learn one side star on your good side. You are going to need to learn all the side star versions because they are going to come up in future machines.

lessons.title: Machine: bird, prasarita twist, straddle bat, side star, tick tock
lessons.synopsis: Integrating everything together.
lessons.instructions:
(Most of the transitions are already taught with the poses.)
1. Start in bird.
2. Go to folded leaf.
3. Use paserita twist to go to straddle bat.
4. Go up into side star.
5. Come back into straddle bat.
6. Go to side star on the other side.


Tic Toc---
Tic toc is a famous flow. It’s basically starting in straddle bat and going to side star on opposite sides over and over. It’s so famous because it’s relatively simple yet looks very amazing. Non-acroyoga friends and family can often be more impressed by tic tocs than actually challenging acroyoga work.

lessons.title: Warm-up 1: Shoulders on Thigh Bridge
lessons.synopsis: A fun and easy inversion.
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back and assumed bridge pose (feet flat on the ground, knees bent, and hips high).
2. The flyer stands at the feet of the base and places their shoulders on the base’s thigh near the knee (not on the knee!).
3. The flyer places their hands on the base’s shin: Fingers pointing down, index and middle finger split over the thigh bone, and elbows at about a 45-degree angle.
4. The flyer jumps their hips over their shoulder to enter a shoulderstand.


Motivation:---
This level is about introducing star pose (inversion on the base’s feet). This particular warm-up is an easy way to experience an inversion and become comfortable with being upside down. Even if flyers don’t have headstands, shoulderstands, or handstands in their practice, this is a pretty easy way to get inverted.


Tip:---
- The base can squeeze their thighs around the flyer’s neck to help with stability.

- If the base raises their arms up, the base can spot a flyer when the flyer falls backwards. Simply aim for the butt of the falling flyer and support.

- If a flyer struggles to get inverted a scissor lift can help:
(1) The flyer raises one leg as high as possible.
(2) The helper puts a hand under the foot in the air so that the flyer can push against it.
(3) The flyer raises their second leg and with the help of the supported foot and bring the second leg vertical.


Spotting:---
The spotter should have the hands on both sides of the flyer’s hips to control falls in any direction.


Deeper Cuts:---
Once the flyer is a little bit comfortable, it’s a good idea to start doing leg motions to develop comfort in inversion:
- Legs straight up
- Front split
- Side split
- Knees tugged to the chest

lessons.title: Warm-up 2: Barnacle on Cow Pose
lessons.synopsis: A different way to invert.
lessons.instructions:
1. The base is in quadrupet position or on their hands and knees with a neutral spine.
2. The flyer stands on the side of the base.
3. The flyer places one arm along the base’s arm so that the flyer’s elbow crease is on the base’s shoulder. The flyer’s lower arm should extend down the base’s upper arm. And the flyer’s upper arm should go straight across the back.
4. The flyer’s other arm should go under the belly of the base. That arm’s elbow crease should be on the side of the base.
5. The flyer places their chest across the back of the base. The chin should stick over the base’s body so that the flyer doesn’t choke. (This may cause a suboptimal arm position based on the dimensions of the two bodies.)
6. The flyer can now hop their hips over their shoulders to do a cheststand on the base.


Motivation---
This is another way to easily put a flyer into an inversion to create more comfort for star pose.


Spotting---
The spotter should have their hands on both sides of the hips of the flyer.


Deeper Cuts---
It’s actually pretty easy for the base to lift their hips to bring crouch on their feet with the arms still on the ground. From this crouch, it’s relatively easy to slowly stand up. Obviously, the base can’t stand up straight without the flyer falling off. The base has to stand hunched forward to give the flyer as flat as a surface as possible. From here, it’s quite feasible to go for a walk.

Note: Standing up requires more careful spotting because the flyer has now a riskier fall.

lessons.title: Warm-up 3: Forward Roll
lessons.synopsis: A very useful preparation for entering star.
lessons.instructions:
1. The student places their chin on their chest. This is important because it prevents the chin getting slammed against the chest (tongue biting and chipped teeth).
2. The student places their hands on the ground.
3. The student places the top or back of their head on the ground.
4. The student curls the back as much as possible.
5. The students rolls forward to roll over the spine to end up in a seated position.


Motivation---
A lot of students have initially trouble jumping into star pose as a flyer. The trick is often that the student needs to think less about jumping but more about rolling into the pose. The forward roll is a great exercise to practice rounding the back and rolling forward. (This pose may be well familiar to students who have learned it as kids in PhysEd. However, some students have never learned this.)


Tips---
- A partner can help with a hand on the back to slow down the roll initially. That avoids slamming the back on the ground.

- If the back slams on the ground, the student doesn’t round their back enough.

- If the student jumps into the roll, encourage them not to jump but simply roll.


Deeper Cuts---
The roll can be done in reverse, which is a good exercise. The mechanics are slightly different.

1. Again start by tugging the chin onto the chest.
2. Sit on the butt.
3. Place the hands above the shoulders with the palms facing back and the wrists up.
4. Roll backwards towards the head with a very rounded spine.
5. When the head reaches the floor, push up with the hands to make the head move under the body.
6. The student should end up on their feet in a squat/crouch.

lessons.title: Technique Drill: Tripod Headstand
lessons.synopsis: Exploring entering and alignment in an inversion on your own.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start sitting on your knees.
2. Place your hands on the ground in front of you.
3. Place your head on the ground so that your head and hands form an even-sided triangle on the ground.
4. Come to your toes so that your hips go high.
5. Try to walk your feet as close as possible to your face.
6. Lift one leg as high as possible.
7. Use the leg on the ground to hop your hips over your shoulders so that you find inverted balance.
8. The most easily balanced leg position is to be in a wide side split. (Think how tightrope walkers use a very wide stick to help them with balance.)

Alternative: If it’s hard to get your feet up due to flexibility, you can also add an intermediate step: Put your knees on your elbows before you shoot your legs up.)


Motivation:---
Before introducing star, we want to give students as much opportunity to experience inversions on their own. Tripod headstand is a great way to explore leg range mobility and to simply become familiar with being upside down on your own terms.


Alternative:---
A different arm placement might make finding balance harder but provide more comfort for the head. Place your hands on the ground so that your index fingertips and thumb tips are touching the same of the opposite hand. In between the thumbs and index finger should be a vague rectangle. You can use this as a cradle for your. And then your forearms will be flat on the ground, creating an open-sided triangle.


Tips:---
- You can use a wall or spotter to prevent falling over.
- A folded-up yoga mat or other cushion may provide more comfort for the head to be on the ground.
- A partner can put their fist between the ankles of the inverted person and ask to squeeze. This can help create better alignment.
- Some people do not know how to align their bodies headover. A partner can help guide the inverted person into a more balanced position. Softly touching a body part and asking “Coem more this way!” can be a great way of communicating and guiding.

lessons.title: Position lesson 1: Star
lessons.synopsis: The magic of being upside down on someone's feet.
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back and brings their arms up in a nice bone stack.
2. The flyer approaches the base from the base’s head and connects hands (see hand connection below).
3. The base presents the feet.
4. The flyer places their shoulders onto the feet (see foot connection below).
5. To prepare, the base lowers their feet as much as possible. The flyer steps as close as possible. This will require a bit of negotiation. The goal is to get the flyer’s hips as close as possible to being above the shoulders of the flyer.
6. The flyer rounds their back as much as possible and jumps into the inversion (see tips for entering star below).
7. The easiest way for the flyer to balance is to be in a wide side split.
8. The base straightens their legs to find their bone stack.
9. The base rotates their heels together so that the flyer can press the back of their head against the base’s heels for extra stability. (Depending on the flyer’s head position, the flyer might have to move the head forward and out of the way.)
10. Check that the flyer’s arm position is in front of the shoulders and bent. The flyer should put light weight into the hands by leaning the whole body forward.


Motivation---
Star is one of the grand poses. It’s eye-popping to passersby to see a person inverted on top of another person. With bird, throne, straddle bat, and side star, throne is one of the cornerstone poses that many washing machines flow through. This is an introduction to star. There is an entire level later dedicated to intermediate-level star.


Hand Connection---
The hand connection is unexpected and a little challenging for beginners to pick up. However, it’s important. Practicing the very first warm-up “Flashlights” now demonstrates why it’s such a beneficial practice. Like in the warm-up, the focus is on pushing the two base knuckles of the index and middle finger out. Beginners tend to have a challenge to differentiate between turning their wrist and pushing those two knuckles out.

To prepare, the flyer and base want to get a good visualizing of where the two base knuckles of the index and middle finger are as well as the fleshy mound/pillow below the thumb on the palm. The flyer’s two knuckles shoulder press agains the upper edge fo the base’s fleshy mound below the thumb on the palm. The base wants to do the same to the flyer.

Thus the hand connection is at those two connection points. The hands shouldn’t slide in towards each other like a handshake where the webbing between the thumb and index finger gets stuck against each other. It’s not only a bad connection, but also painful.

With the hand thus connected, the partners should put the index and middle finger on the wrist of their partner and wrap the ring and pinkie finger around the back of the palm of the partner. “Two on the wrist and two wrapped” is the saying to remember this.

The next choice is the angle at the wrist. There are two extreme cases. The wrist can be completely straight (steep) or complietely flat (bent backwards). The preferred wrist angle is somewhere in between. Individual wrists are different. It’s good for the flyer and base to negotiate an angle that feels mutually good. Once the angle is chosen with the flyer on the ground, the same angle should be locked in and maintained.


Spotting---
The spotter should be partially behind the base’s legs and partially to the side of them. The goal is to strike a happy medium between having the spotter’s body in the way of the flyer falling backwards and still being able to observe the face of the base. (Facial expressions are often early warning signs of trouble.)

The hand of the spotter should be hover a quarter inch close to both sides of the flyer’s hip.

Be sure to reach forward as the flyer comes up and guide the flyer all the way down when they exit. Novice flyers may feel scared of exiting and stepping on the base’s head. It’s unlikely to happen, but a little extra assurance by slowing them down can be comforting.


How To Get Into Star---
Many flyers have initially trouble getting into star. Most people can be coached through it. Here are tips on how to get into star. They are listed in the order that makes the most sense to work through them.

1. Lower the base’s feet as much as possible. A lower base means less distance for the flyer to get up.

2. The flyer should be fairly close to the base. Flyers tend to walk their feet away from the base due to flexibility especially when the base lowers the feet more. However, flyers need to be close to the base as this allows them to direct their jump energy up instead of forward to get to the base.

3. One of the biggest issues and the one which flyers are often stuck on for a long time is this: The focus should NOT be to jump up but to press their flyer’s shoulders down onto the base. With that focus, flyers tend to jump up their whole body and even lift their shoulders off the feet of the base. Instead by focusing on rolling forward, the flyers keep their shoulders on the bases feet and focus more on using their arms and core to press their legs up.

4. Round the flyer’s back. Like in the forward roll, the more the flyer rounds their back, the closer they are to already being up.

5. Base’s need to present strong arms as high as possible. (Beginning base’s often bend their arms.) The more a flyer presses into the hand connection the less jump is needed. Accomplished flyers can enter star without jumping at all, simply by pressing.

Note: There is a tendency to help struggling flyers too early. It’s a gift to allow a flyer a few attempts to figure it out on their own before they are placed into the position.


How To Balance In Star---
To some degree, the base and flyer have to gain experience in this position to balance better. Flyer’s might feel so disoriented that they need some guidance from a spotter to find their balance. However, there are specific things to do to improve the balance. Below is a list that everyone should implement.

1. The flyer should relax their neck. There is a tendency to have at tense neck because everything is so exciting. However, the neck muscles aren’t needed. Relaxing the neck muscles allows the base’s feet to sink deeper and create a better connection. (Think of how a pumped-up ball easily rolls away, but a flat deflated ball stays in place.)

2. The flyer’s arms should be bent and as close as possible at a ninety-degree angle. There should be weight in them. The center of gravity of the flyer should be between their shoulders and hands. Balancing entirely on the shoulders is a more difficult skill. Plus, it provides some assurance that the flyer won’t fall backwards.

3. The base should put their heels together and the flyer should press the back of their head against the base’s shin. This creates extra stability.

4. When the flyer holds their legs in a side split, it’s the most stable leg position. As the flyer becomes more comfortable, the flyer can venture out into more precarious leg positions.


Sport Vs. Comfort Foot Position (and other considerations)---
Rather than thinking of a correct foot position, there are different placements for different purposes. The main choice is to keep the feet in a V with the heels touching or to keep the feet parallel. You can think of this choice as the comfort versus the sports version. The V position allows the flyer to push their head back and gets extra stability. The parallel position is less stable, yet allows the flyer to move into different positions as well as exit into or enter from different positions.

The other choice is where on the base’s foot to place the flyer’s shoulders. For example, if the flyer’s is on the balls of the feet, the flyer has considerable “runway” towards the back. This allows the flyer to lean backwards. If the flyer brings their feet forward as a counterbalance, a flyer can lean their body almost horizontally back.

In the opposite direction, if the flyer is on the base’s heel, the base can offer the feet on the flyer’s chest for the flyer lean forward. If the base needs to get the feet out easily, it might make sense to place the flyer even onto the toes of the base. A common usage of that is to enter hand-to-hand and be able to very gently pull the feet out.


Leg Range Of Motion---
As earlier mentioned, in inversions, it’s good to go through legs straight up, side split, front split, knees to chest, and so on.

Another good thing is to play with the counterbalance between he hips and the feet. A flyer can bring their hips backwards and their feet forward. If the weight of either side of their shoulder is equal, the flyer can fold their legs towards their chest that way.

A useful variation of that is to pancake. A pancake on the floor is when you sit with your legs straight and wide while you touch your chest on the floor. Trying to assume the same thing inverted in the air is “pancaking.” Practicing this is very useful for future progressions.

lessons.title: Position lesson 2: Foot-to-hand
lessons.synopsis: Another iconic pose for your quiver.
lessons.instructions:
Before starting the pose, it’s a good idea to feel the hand connection first:
1. The flyer! lies down on their belly and bends the feet to a ninety-degree angle to present the feet.
2. The base can now connect the hands to find the right position and show the flyer the preferred foot angle. (For hand connection, see below.)
3. The flyer should memorize the foot angle and commit it to memory.

Ready to do actual foot-to-hand:
1. The base lies on their back with their legs nicely stacked. The elbows are on the ground at the side. The wrist is stacked right on top of the elbow.
2. The flyer steps over the belly of the base looking at the base’s feet.
3. The flyer will hold the base’s feet for support.
4. The flyer will lift and present a foot.
5. The base will grab the foot, adjust the grip, and angle. (For hand connection, see below).
6. The base will place their elbow on the ground.
7. The flyer should wait until the base gives the go ahead to put weight on the base.
8. The same is repeated on the other side. (The flyer should not rush but go through the same presenting and weighting for the elbow to be placed before putting any weight on.)
9. As the flyer is now standing, the flyer can try to balance without holding onto the base’s feet.
10. To step down, the flyer can put their weight on the base’s feet.

Note: Flyers often assume priority and extra consideration. In this pose, it’s the base’s fragile wrist against the entire body weight of the flyer. Thus, the base requires priority and extra consideration. For example, flyers tend to right away step on the base. Instead, the flyer should present the foot and allow the base to choose the preferred angle and place the foot in position before placing any weight on it. Flyers may assume that their balance takes priority and tell the base how to hold the foot. In this case, serious pain and injury can come from this. The flyer has to work to achieve the hand position and angle that the base needs.


Motivation---
This is a wonderful dimension to stretch the yoga practice into. Standing on the base and holding the base with the hands is a different realm and opens up many wonderful opportunities.


Spotting---
The spotter should stand on the side of the flyer. The spotter should put one arm in front and one arm behind the flyer at the hip level to create a “cage.” if the flyer were to fall, the spotter can bear hug the flyer to catch him or her.

This is a case where a base can benefit from spotting as well. The base can be at risk of having their arms pushed out and to hurt their shoulder. A spotter can place a foot where the base’s elbow is on the ground. That way the spotter’s shin can prevent the base from having their arm getting twisted outwards.


Foot Connection---
There are different ways to connect the base’s hand and the flyer’s foot. Some instructors will teach that only one ways is correct. Others will admit that different preferences exist, particularly if the instructor found that they prefer a different hold.

The most common connection has the base focus the base knuckles of their index and middle finger on the distal part (the side towards the toes) of the flyer’s heel. The heel is a pretty easily discernable oval shape. The base’s index and middle finger go across the heel. The base’s ring and pinkie finger wrap around the arch of the foot.

The important part is the angle of the ankle. The base has to choose an angle that works for them. The flyer must maintain the angle. Usually, the base tries to accommodate the flyer. However, in this case, the weight of the flyer is of a much larger magnitude than the strength of a human wrist. Thus, to avoid injury, the flyer has to accomodate the base.

A common alternative is the Lego-person grip or C-grip. The flyer makes a C-shape with their hand. The index finger and thumb create the C-shape. The base puts the C-shape across the flyer’s foot.

Other variations are that the base only puts one finger over the flyer’s heel and the rest around the flyer’s arch of the foot.

Personally, I use the C-grip with beginning flyers. I’ve experienced too many beginning flyers leaning into their heels to create pain. Even flyers who aren’t that bad tend to build up enough discomfort in the wrist to where one has to stop basing after a few minutes. With the C-grip, the base’s wrist is protected. When a flyer can maintain a good angle, I switch to the other grip because it allows more control.


Tips---
- Communicating “more toes” or “more heels” is a way for the base to ask to change the angle of the flyer’s foot. It’s important to talk about this before.

- Sometimes based on hand/foot geometry, flyers will feel that they have to balance on their heels. Some of them believe that it’s impossible to give more toes (change the ankle angle like one would when wearing a taller high heel). However, it’s quite possible. One can simple stand on a stair by only having the heel on the stair and the rest of the foot overhanging. One can raise and lower the front of the foot in that position. This image (or actually) trying out might help a flyer who believes this to be impossible.


Deeper Cuts/Progressions---
Typically, a flyer/base pair will start with this exercise by having the flyer put a lot of their body weight onto the base’s feet. As the flyer becomes more comfortable, the flyer can take more weight out of their hands until hands are no longer needed.

The base may ease this transition by supporting the flyer’s balance with the base’s knees. Some flyers get used to this support, but the base should take it eventually away.

The next step is to do foot-to-hand with extended arms. This means the base lifts their elbows of the ground and straightens their arms.

Typically, this is first attempted by using a process called “boxing up.” The flyer holds the base’s feet and puts as much weight as possible on the base’s feet. This eases the load on the flyer’s arms to make it easier for the base to press up the arms. Once the base has extended and locked out their arms, the flyer can transfer their weight back onto the base’s hands.

This seems to be called boxing up because from the side, the silhouette of the flyer and base are a rectangle (= box-shaped).


About Pose Names---
A common acroyoga naming convention is to state two body parts. Those are the two body parts that are connected. The first body part always belongs to the flyer. The second body part belongs to the base.

So “foot-to-hand” means the flyer’s foot is on top of the base’s hand. In contrast, “hand-to-foot” means the flyer’s hands are on the base’s feet. (I’m not sure that there is a convention for what the latter actually means. The flyer could be doing a handstand or an L-sit on the flyer’s feet.)

lessons.title: Position lesson 3: Reverse throne
lessons.synopsis: A useful way to exit foot-to-hand.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start in foot-to-hand (see previous pose.
1. The base moves there legs through in between the flyer’s legs towards the face of the base.
2. The base places their feet onto the butt of the flyer.
3. The flyer sits back.
4. The base straightens their legs.

Note: Reverse throne feels a bit unstable. The related reverse straddle throne is more comfortable. However, reverse throne is a useful in between pose to exit out of the foot-to-hand. The base can easily place the flyer on the ground from here. In case of instability, the base can often also catch the flyer with this pose.


Motivation---
Learning reverse throne is a good complement to foot-to-hand. It’s also a way that an unsteady flyer can be caught when being upright and facing away from the base from a variety of transitions.


Tips---
Develop a stable foot-to-hand before attempting this.

For less stable base/flyer pairs, it can be helpful to leave one of the base’s feet in front of the flyer and one behind. That way, the base can transition one foot at a time in place while helping the flyer stabilize.

lessons.title: Machine: star, foot-to-hand, reverse throne, bonus: reverse shoulder stand.
lessons.synopsis: Putting it all together into a fun flow.
lessons.instructions:
1. Start in star.
2. The flyer should slide their hands to the wrist of the base.
3. The base should open their hands wide.
4. The base should bend their knees to help the flyer with the next move.
5. The flyer will slowly bring their feet towards the hands of the base. To avoid falling forward, the flyer has to lean their butt back in a counterbalance to the feet going forward and down.
6. The flyer might not have the skill to reach their feet all the way to the base’s hands. There might be a little fall.
7. The flyer will maintain weight in the shoulders while the base guides the flyer’s feet to the foot-to-hand position.
8. While the above happens, the flyer transitions their hands to hold on the base’s ankles.
9. The flyer stands up into foot-to-hand.
10. The base moves their feet in between the flyer’s leg to land on the flyer’s butt.
11. The flyer sits back on to the base’s feet. And the base extends their legs.
12. The base places the flyer on the ground.


Motivation:---
The transition from star to foot-to-hand is a bit surprising at first because it’s a 180 degree turn. However, it’s quite doable and a pleasant surprise when one can achieve it pretty quickly.


Tips---
For the flyer to bring the feet to the base’s hands requires a counter balance. Equal weight should be in front of the flyer’s shoulders (the weight of the legs) and behind the flyer’s shoulders (the butt sticking out). A flyer can practice going as deep as possible and back out of this counterbalance a few times before going for the flow.
