lessons.title: Transferring Walking Skills To Bachata
lessons.synopsis: Develops bachata movement intuitively from how you naturally walk.
lessons.instructions:
1. Walk in a circle to bachata music.
2. Relax and listen to the music until your pace naturally synchronizes with the beat of the music.
3. Relax and let your arms swing more and body move.
4. Observe how there is natural opposition of the opposite leg and arm moving forward.
5. Observe and notice the natural inclination of the hip to rotate in the opposite direction of the chest.
6. Walk like a New Yorker, very tense and pointed.
7. Walk like you own a beach bar in the Caribbean, your shirt is open, a beer is in your hand, and the ocean breeze is caressing your skin. Notice how your hips swing a lot more.
8. Walk like you are a black panther stalking. Observe all the isolations in your body and how your wagging, invisible tail makes you move as well.


Motivation:---
Most new dance students move very awkwardly and struggle with basic movements. It’s like as soon as they are in a dance studio, they forget to move. There is a neurological explanation. Our conscious awareness comes mostly from the prefrontal cortex of the brain. If we try to move consciously, we use the prefrontal cortex. The prefrontal cortex is very good at solving complicated problems. However, it can only hold a very limited number of things in its attention. It’s not very well suited for learning movement - even though that’s how most dance instruction has been traditionally delivered.

The motor cortex is really good at doing whole-body movements. We spend years developing motor programs of complex movements like walking, riding a bicycle, or reaching for a jar on a high shelf. You may think of reaching for a jar on a high shelf as an arm movement only. However, your shoulder has to lift. Your hips have to tilt for an extra inch. And your opposite foot might reach out to counterbalance. All of that happens without us thinking about it. We think about the goal and allow the motor cortex to execute its motor program.

This introduction exercise takes a motor program that you’ve been practicing for twenty or more years - “walking” - and makes you play with it by giving you different imagery. As you observe yourself, you’ll notice that all the styling movements that you need for bachata dancing are hinted at and already included in your natural walking skill. Using insights from your walking study will give you movement patterns that you will be able to reuse in bachata movement technique (instead of trying to learn them from scratch).


Common Problems:---
1. NOT MOVING TO THE MUSIC: Some students with little dance background will walk completely disconnected from the music. The music may appear like an impenetrable forest. I believe the movie “Dead Poet Society” had a scene where the teacher asked the students NOT to move to the beat. After fifteen minutes, even the iron-willed student succumbed to the music. This is a promise that if you relax, the music will take over. The more you try, the more tense you may become, and the more blocked from the music you may be. This exercise may move you forward by quantum leaps. Simply focus your mind on the music, relax, and keep walking. You may have a blissful surprise experience that suddenly you start to feel things in the music like the beat.

2. STIFF, TIGHT MOVEMENTS: Some students will naturally walk very stiffly. They won’t move their arms at all. There is no swing in the hips. This is an excellent exercise to work on before getting bombarded with technique. Moving stiff and tight may be the natural result of living a life that’s very office desk focused and may also have components of feeling shy or disconnected from the body. Walking and letting a hand move back and forth may be start. Feel how the swing of the hand gives you a natural impetus for your leg to swing in the opposite way. Observe how these natural impulses and momentums become stronger and weaker. An arm swinging at the top of its range before it changes directions is slower than at the bottom of the pendulum swing. When you allow more of this to happen, you’ll start feeling pulls on your hips and shoulders as well. Observe and allow more of this to happen. You are developing a relationship to your body.

lessons.title: Bachata Movement Technique From The Feet Up
lessons.synopsis: Develops bachata movement explicitly so that you can control every element.
lessons.instructions:
1. Stand with good posture and your feet next to each other, pointing forward.

2. Move one foot to point your toes to the ground. Press the balls of your feet onto the ground. Press your heel down. Repeat with the other foot. This familiarizes us with your foot.

3. Change the pattern to only go between the balls of the feet and the heels while pressing to the beat of the music. This familiarizes us with pressing into the ground.


4. Continue the movement. Additionally, when you are on the balls of your feet, allow your knee to bend more. This should make the hip drop down. Keep the chest still and in place. You’ll find it challenge to coordinate all these body parts. Mentally focus on relaxing the side of your body and let the actual movement be a result of your focus to relax.

5. Let the last exercises go. Imagine that your legs extend into your belly and have become tree trunks that don’t move. Hold your arms straight out to the side. Move your shoulders side to side. Importantly, your shoulders parallel to the ground. You can visualize this more as your rib cage sliding left and right rather than a tilt. Do this to the music for a while.

6. The arms straight out to the side were there to help you keep your shoulders horizontal. Let your arms come down and in front of your belly as if you are holding a baby.

7. If you feel comfortable with the ribcage movement, turn your hands over and start moving you arms subtly as a consequence of your chest movement, not on their own.

8. Let the last exercise go. Return to the first exercise, where you were kneading the ground with your feet and allowed your knees and hips to move with the movement. Do that for a while to music to bring it back to mind.

9. Keep going with the lower body exercise and now introduce the upper body exercise. When you are on the balls of your feet, your knee above should relax, the hip tilt down, and the ribcage should move on top of it to that side.


Motivation:---
You may have seen ballroom dancers with completely stiff upper bodies gliding over the dancefloor in an embrace that doesn’t change. That’s not bachata! The body movements are very important in interpreting and enjoying the music. Stylistically, this is what makes dancers look good. Practically, to lead and dance the sensual movements, we have to dedicate a big focus on developing these movements.

A saying is that you are only as advanced as your basic. With that, people don’t mean that you know the basic step pattern but that you know how to move your body. Some beginners may feel uncomfortable with these movements. They may also innocently disregard it as unfamiliar and probably unimportant. Yet this is the heart of dancing bachata.


Tips:---
There is no intellectual shortcut to learning movement technique. It requires practice.

Route repetition is maybe what old dance cliches suggest. However, if you are mentally checked out and repeating the same movement for hours, you are not learning a lot. Instead, put on a bachata song that you like (or even explore non-bachata music) and move your body to the music roughly within the parameters of the prescribed movement. (Don’t go all old disco side step here.)

Play a little with the music. If the music goes lower, let your body go lower. Play with what if you move your hips more side to side horizontally or tilt them up and down. Play with making the movement way too big and then way too small. What can you learn from that? Does this unlock something new in your body? Try to not do anything and focus only on the music to let your body surprise you in which new ways it suddenly moves intuitively.

lessons.title: The Basic Step Pattern
lessons.synopsis: Learn the foot work for the basic.
lessons.instructions:
1. Repeat the body movement from the previous lesson to music.

2. Once you are comfortable doing the body movement, take a step to the side and a step together. You want to coordinate your step with your ribcage moving in the same direction. Keep going like that all the way to the other side of the room. Keep walking side-to-side like that.

3. If you are comfortable with that, start switching directions sooner. Take three steps. Tap your foot and start in the other direction for three steps and a tap. Keep going in your small “box.”


Motivation:---
The basic step pattern of three steps and a tap is often taught right away. It makes people very focused on intellectualizing the steps. By starting with a merengue movement, it doesn’t take a lot of mental focus and we can stay focused on the quality of the body movement. Once moving side-to-side starts becoming automatic, we can make another small change to do the actual bachata basic.


Bachata Basic Step Pattern:---
Summary: (Moving left) Left, right, left, tap; (Moving right) right, left, right, tap.

0. To start, stand with your weight on your right foot. Your left foot is tapped. Tapped means that there is no weight on it. The heel is up. The balls of the foot are next to the middle of the foot with the weight.

1. Start by shifting your ribcage to the left and step out with the left foot. Commit your complete body weight.

2. Shift your ribcage back to the right. Move the right foot to meet the left foot and commit your body weight.

3. Make another step to the left.
4. Push your ribcage again to the left. Your right hip should pop up a bit. Place tap your right foot next to your left foot.

5-8. Repeat in the other direction.


Tips:---
- It’s easy to get confused on the steps. Always commit 100% of your weight to the foot that you stepped with (unless it’s a tap.) That will make clear which foot to use next: The one without weight. Then it becomes almost a no-brainer.

- The hips should swing opposite to the step direction and the shoulder movement. Think “leaving your hips behind” when stepping. More technically precise, you want your hip movements to be on the “and” in the music. The “and” is the midpoint between two beats.

lessons.title: Hip Movement Patterns
lessons.synopsis: Learn the hip movements for the basic.
lessons.instructions:
1. Traditional hips: Lead with your chest in the direction of your step. Let the hips pop out on the opposite side. On the tap, keep your chest on the same side and pop your tapping hip a little up.

2. Practice sensual hips: Circle one knee. Once that works, allow the knee circles to move the hip on that side. Repeat with the other knee. Keep switching between the knees in shorter and shorter intervals until you switch after each circle. Your hips should now be doing an infinity circle.

3. Alternative practice for sensual hips: Move your left hip towards the front left corner of the room. Circle the left hip back towards the back left corner of the room. Slide your hips diagonally forward so that your right hip goes towards the front right corner of the room. Circle your right hip back towards the back right corner. Keep going. (Also try reversing the direction.)

4. Sensual hips: Do the sensual hips while doing the basic.

5. Practice circular hips: Move your hips in a big circle. Try the other direction as well.

6. Circular hips: Do the basic while moving your hips in a big circle. You can start the circle moving forward with the hips and backward. Try both!

7. Bonus: U-hips: As you start on 1, your hips dip down. On 2, they come back up. You continue like that.


Motivation:---
Hip movements are a big part of bachata. Which once you choose depends on your styling choice and the music. Traditional and sensual hips are the main choices and come from the traditional and respectively sensual bachata. As such, they have their own flavor that might fit better to different music and sections within a song. Circular hips are less common but a styling option. The U-shaped movement is rarely taught, but a fun thing to have in your back pocket if the moment calls for it.


Common problems:---
- SHOULDER AND HIP DISSOCIATION: Some beginners have trouble moving their hips and shoulders in opposite directions. This is a key skill to develop for Latin dances. There are various tricks that help people figure it out. For example, try to touch your knee to your opposite elbow. This naturally rotates the hips and shoulder in opposite directions. Another one is to look over your shoulder and try to see your butt cheek on the other side.

- HIP INFINITY CIRCLES: These tend to be tricky for people. The instructions outline two different ways to learn them. Follow those instructions very slowly. Slower means that you have an easier time doing it. Keep repeating it, focusing on precision instead of speed. You’ll notice that you’ll naturally speed up as the movement gets more ingrained until you can do it to the speed of music.

lessons.title: Chest-Lead, Hip-Lead, And Foot-Lead Movement
lessons.synopsis: A focus exercise to refine your body movement.
lessons.instructions:
(It’s the same movement for each part of the exercise. However, where you place your mental focus and what body part drives the movement changes.)

1. CHEST-LED: Do the bachata basic with the hip and chest movement techniques as we learned it so far. However, place your conscious focus on your chest and how your chest leads into whichever direction you step. For example, as you step to the left, you lean your chest to the left. As a consequence to keep your balance, your hips will have to move to the right to counterbalance. Your whole body is shifted as a consequence of your chest movement. We want to think of our mental focus on one body part, and the rest of the body moves as a consequence without us putting focus onto it.

2. HIP-LED: We are doing the same thing as the previous part. The difference is that we are focusing on our hip and allowing everything else to move as a consequence. Notice how each body part brings a different quality. The hips have a lot of control. Thus, they can capture and mimic the feel of an instrument or voice very well. Sounds have a quality to them, like flat, hollow, sharp, light, heavy, and so on. You can capture that very well with the hips.

3. FOOT-LED: We are repeating the same exercise. However, this time, we are focusing on the feet and allowing everything else to move as a consequence. The energetic quality to focus on is to “draw energy from the floor” and push into the floor. Another tactile quality to play with is to massage the floor in the way that a cat kneads one with its paws.


MOTIVATION---
Most students encounter the body and in particular hip movements at some point in a class. However, as soon as the class moves on from hip exercises to stepping, they forget all about the body movements. It’s difficult and feels awkward. So they avoid it. Instructors will often repeatedly call to move the hips, but that call becomes repetitive and ignored. This lesson offers a way to develop the hip movement without being repetitive. By shifting the focus, it gives the mind something to do. Plus, it allows us to improve different aspects of the movement technique.


NOTE
Hip-led doesn't mean that the hip moves first in the direction of movement. The movement pattern still stays the same. The hip stays behind. It's the internal focus that changes - not the movement.

lessons.title: Finding The "1" In Music
lessons.synopsis: Develop musical understanding to find the point when to start dancing.
lessons.instructions:
This lesson is a mixture of lecture and body drumming exercises to experience the musical concept. Body drumming is using your own body to create rhythm, e.g. clap your hands, slap your thighs, pound your chest. You’ll have to keep the body drumming rhythm for a few minutes until your music ear starts picking up on the feeling of the particular exercise. The reason is that at first, you’ll do the exercise using your conscious mind. When the exercise becomes automatic, your musical feeling will take over. And the goal of the exercise is to develop your musical feeling. If you only do the exercise once and out of rhythm, you won’t get the benefit out of it.


LECTURE: TIME SIGNATURE:---
Before medieval times (and outside of Western music), musical notes used to go all over the place without a clear start, end, or pattern. Then some people realized that if we put the notes into regular groupings of notes, it gives the ears something recognizable. The groupings are called bars. And the type of grouping is described by its time signature.

You’ve probably seen numbers at the start of sheet music. There are often two numbers over each other like a fraction, but they don’t have a line in between. That’s the time signature. The top number describes how many notes are in a bar. The bottom number describes the duration of the notes. For example, 3 over 4 says that there are 3 notes in the bar. And they are a quarter (1/4) long. Another example is 2 over 2: Two notes that are half a note long (1/2).


LECTURE: METER:---
An observant person may ask: How does one know where a bar starts and ends? After all if all the notes sounded the same, they may appear as groups on the sheet music, but there is no way to hear where the bar starts and ends.

The meter answers that question. The meter describes which notes are stressed and unstressed. By the convention of Western music, the first note in a bar is always stressed.

Examples:
- Unmetered: If we slap our thighs left and right perfectly equally, we have an unmetered sound. There is no meter. There is no emphasis.

- 2 over 2: If we slap hard with the left hand on the thigh and softly with the right, we create a sound that sounds like marching music: LEFT - right - LEFT - right. And most marching music is in a meter with 2 on top.

- 3 over 4: If we want to create a 3 over 4 meter, we have to slap HARD - soft - soft - HARD - soft - soft. You’ll notice that this is familiar from the Viennese Waltz. Indeed, they are written in that meter. The dance is often a big step forward and two small steps in place. Thus the movement mimics the meter.

- 4 over 4: We have finally arrived at the time signature for bachata: 4 over 4. You may have an expectation about what the meter should be based on the current rule. However, it’s a little different. 4 over 4 is: STRONG - weak - Medium - weak - STRONG… Yes, we’ve introduced medium-strong beats into the music.


EXERCISE: METER:---
Let’s practice this meter. If you are at home, take 10-15 minutes or longer to play with STRONG - weak - MEDIUM - weak at the experiential level. You are training your ears. This isn’t simply a logical concept to understand.

Let’s start with a body drumming exercise. When you clap your hands, you create a very loud sound. Let’s use that for “STRONG.” When you slap your thighs, you create a pretty loud sound but not as loud. Let’s use that for “Medium.” When you tap your chest, it’ll create a pretty muted sound. Let’s use that for “weak.”

Open your phone and search for “metronome.” Google search will give you a metronome tool. It’ll allow you to select a speed (BPM). Start the metronome. This will give you a constant beat so that you stay on time. Then start clapping to it. Once you are synced with the metronome, try to create the bachata meter:
1. Clap your hands (“STRONG”)
2. Tap your chest (“weak”)
3. Slap your thigh (“Medium”)
4. Tap your chest (“weak”)
5. Start at 1 again.

Now that you have a bit of a feel for it. Let’s try to create 4/4 by slapping your thigh. You have to slap your thigh harder and softer based on the meter. This takes a little more skill to keep the time of the metronome and dose the strength of your slaps.

Now that this is working, try to squeeze someone’s shoulder (not painfully hard) to transmit 4/4 with stronger, medium, and weaker squeezes.

You are on a roll! Try to to create the 4/4 meter with your voice. Pick something like “la” and sing: LA - la - La - la


LECTURE: FINDING THE METER IN MUSIC---
Play a bachata song and see if you can find the pulse in music (STRONG - weak - Medium - weak). Usually, not a single instrument will play continuously on the beat during a bar. The beat is created by all the instruments and the voice working together.

On a side note, bachata is actually a polyrhythm. Poly means many. Each instrument has its own rhythm. Their combination is what gives us the overall beat.

People often listen for the bongos to find a strong bongo sound indicating the start of a musical bar. However, you can also listen to the voice. Each syllable will have a different amount of stress placed on it. And the stress follows the meter.


LECTURE: FINDING THE 1 IN MUSIC---
If you are very perceptive, you may notice that a musical bar has 4 notes but the bachata basic has 8 steps. This discrepancy is actually very common in dance. For musicians, small units of 2, 3, or 4 notes are usually very handy. However, dancers can’t do much with such a short unit. The solution is that dancers often use two bars of music for one bar of dance.

The musicians help the dancers by playing one musical bar strong and the second musical bar weaker. That way dancers know when their “1” starts and when they should start dancing.

Again if you paid attention, just how much a note is stressed is described by its position. For example, 1 and 5 are both the first note of a musical bar. So both should be strongly emphasized. However, 5 should be emphasized a little bit less. Thus, we can differentiate 1 and 5.

The first musical bar often sets a theme that the second bar repeats but in a milder form. With a bit of humor, I make myself the example that on the first bar, the singer belts: “I love you so much!!!!” On the second bar, he quietly adds: “But I love your little sister as well.”


TIPS FOR FINDING THE 1---
Most people can most of the time pick out what is 1 or 5. It’s simply the loudest song. (Emphasis in music doesn’t have to be loudest. It can be the highest pitch, the longest-held note, and all kinds of other effects that can create emphasis for the first note). Once you have a possible suspect for 1 and 5, you simply have to wait until the next musical bar starts. Is the next bar more intense or less intense? If it’s less intense, then your first guess was correct. If it’s more intense, you now have encountered the 1.

Developing the musical ear requires actively (not passively in the background listening to music). You’ll develop a sense of the beat in the music. You’ll recognize which sounds are emphasized as the 1 or which sounds are merely syncopation and decorations. You’ll develop a feel for which is the first bar that sets a theme and which bar repeats the theme.

There are some shortcuts on how to find the 1. Music is the interchange of tension and release. Music is either creating tension or releasing tension. The 1 is so strong that it creates tension. To make it stand out, we want to release tension beforehand. So on 6, you can often here a “ding-ding” that releases the tension. If you hear such a thing, you know that in two notes, the 1 will start.


EXERCISES FOR FINDING THE 1---
- Listen to bachata music to pay attention to the 1 and the 5. Use active listening with your hand. Make a chopping motion with each beat. When you encounter 1 make a very drastic chopping motion. When you encounter 5, make a strong chopping motion.

- Listen to bachata music. Find the 1. When you’ve found it skip to a random part in the song and try to find it again. Keep repeating.

lessons.title: Dancing The Basic With a Partner
lessons.synopsis: Putting everything together to dance the basic with a partner.
lessons.instructions:
1. Find the hand position described below.
2. Listen to the music to find the "1".
3. The leader starts the basic to the left. (The follower has to mirror the leader and starts to the right.)
4. Focus on the chest connection. The chest of the leader should lead in the direction of each step. The follower’s chest should stay squarely and precisely in front of the leader’s chest.


HAND POSITION:---
Bachata has many hand positions. Each position serves a particular function. The hand position that we are learning in this lesson says: “Relax! We are not going to do anything but the basic.”

The follower has her hands in front of her throat. The hands point up like tent walls that have been pulled apart to have a few inches of space in between.

The leader places his hands over the back of her hands. The leader’s base of palm and fingertips slightly press her palm together to hold onto. Key for the leader is to keep his thumb on the side of her palm, not inside. (Placing the palm inside of her palm resembles how a baby holds onto a parent's thumb. We are not looking for that aesthetic.)


MOTIVATION:
This exercise is where student’s practice tends to fall apart, yet they think they are doing awesome because they are finally in a partnered position. Obviously, it’s fun to dance with a partner. However, you want to look at your first steps as a ground zero with a significant climb ahead of you.

Many students tend to not step on the music. They lose all the movement technique to step awkwardly again. They step completely disconnected from their partner. Some students fall into weird habits where they try to shake their body like on a disco dancefloor. This is natural because attending to all those things is absolute information overload.

One way to deal with information overload is to isolate one thing at a time like the previous lessons focused individually on shoulder movements, developing a musical ear, and so on. Now that you’ve danced a song with a partner, you might want to go back and practice the movement on your own in the evening. Or if you have a partner, why not put on some earphones while waiting on the subway and practice some chest isolations together?


PERSPECTIVE:
A lot of beginners are drawn to learning dramatic figures because there is a wow factor to seeing them exquisitely executed by dancers with many years of training. Yet when they do it, they struggle to do it or it won’t look anything like the Instagram example at all because they lack the movement and leading technique underneath it (which is not obvious from watching a demo).

A better goal (which beginners typically don’t know that it exists) is to focus on the quality of movement and musicality. With what you have learned so far, you could spend a year or more really happily dancing. The key is to focus on the music. Every song is unique and packed with emotion. If you sync up your movement with the song and open up your emotions to the song, every song can be deeply enjoyable and unique even if you keep the same three steps and a tap pattern. The fun is not in three steps and a tap (as some students think the step pattern is the secret to dancing). It’s in how much energy you put into each step, how you let the energy in the music drive or soothe your body, and how you hit the instruments in the music as if your body were triggering them. There is a tremendous high when you move in complete sync with your partner. Your breathing synchronizes. And you don’t need any advanced figures to access it. And learning advanced figures is not going to help you access it.


COMMON PROBLEMS:---
- NOISY HAND MOVEMENTS: A lot of beginners get bored and feel like they need to add more. So they start moving their hands in circles. This is discouraged. Hand movements are signals to the follower. For example, raising the hand is often a signal for a turn. If the leader’s hands are really noisy, it’s hard for the follower to tell what’s actually meant to be a signal for her to do something.

- NOT TAPPING: Some people feel uncomfortable about the tap on 4 and 8. It’s something that they may feel unfamiliar with and thus awkward. However, it’s important to keep the time. It’s part of the dance. It also marks for the follower the end of a bar so that she knows where the count is.

- GETTING BORED: People who may be less connected to their bodies and music may feel like they are getting bored of three steps and a tap. They also tend to have poor body movements. Feeling and being in their bodies may be unfamiliar to them. And if you dance only doing the step without body movement and ignoring the music, it indeed can become mechanical. The solution is not to go for more complicated steps, but to learn more about body movement and music. For example, standing and only doing shoulder side-to-side isolations requires a lot of movement skill. Students often song after song struggle to keep their shoulders parallel to the ground. Once the movement starts working out, one can play a lot with the timing of the music. This exercise can develop a lot more sensibility to movement and the music to open up a new world for people who get bored to come back to the basic to discover that there is a lot more.

lessons.title: External Focus Exercise With Masking Tape
lessons.synopsis: A preparatory exercise that speeds up learning the basic step patterns.
lessons.instructions:
(Prerequisites: This lesson requires masking tape and a smooth floor.)

1. Use four strips of masking tape to create a box on the floor. The box should be large enough to fit both your feet and small enough to make it easy to step outside of it.

2. REGULAR BASIC: Start by standing to the right of your box. Step into the box with both feet. Then step out of the box on the left. Keep your right knee raced high. Repeat going into the box. Keep repeating going into the box from both sides. You want to start slowly and smoothly and work up to go as fast as you can. The goal is to arrive at a point where you are simply focused on the box and your feet move in rapid-fire automatic fashion. Mentally, you want to create a sound like “tsh - tsh - tsh - tshuk” that gives you a kind of rhythm to focus on. Each time you have a knee raised, you want to pause a little bit.

3. FORWARD/BACKWARD BASIC: Start by standing behind your box. Have your left knee raised. Step into the box with both feet. Step in front of the box with the right knee raised. Repeat going back and forth.

4. LATERAL BASIC: Start by standing inside the box. Step out with the left leg. Push off to step back into the box and raise the right knee to prepare to go the other side. Keep repeating: Pushing off outside the box and then preparing your knee high on the other side to repeat.

5. BOX STEP/QUADRATO: Start on the back right corner of the box with your left knee raised. Step onto the back left corner. Put your feet together. Step forward with your left foot to the front left corner. Keep the right knee raised to prepare. Continue around the box in the same fashion.


MOTIVATION---
Many people seem to lose the ability to walk normally as soon as they are in a dance class. There is a neurological explanation for it. When people consciously think of moving body parts, they use the prefrontal cortex of the brain. The prefrontal cortex is where the consciousness is. It’s really good at solving complex and intellectual problems. However, it’s very limited in how many things it can keep in focus. Thus, it’s very poor at coordinating many body parts at the same time.

The motor cortex however is excellent at coordinating every part of the body in complex movements. The motor cortex does this by creating “motor programs,” which we develop over many years. For example, our motor program for walking or sitting down has to coordinate every body part. Walking requires a swing of the arms, a tilt of the hip, etc. And it took us years to develop these motor programs. Fast learning of movement comes from reusing the existing motor programs and putting them into a new context.

Choosing between activating the prefrontal cortex and the motor cortex is done by the type of cues and mental focus that we use. Using cues that direct individual body parts makes us use our prefrontal cortex. However, when we focus externally on the box (or use imagery), our prefrontal cortex holds the external focus and the motor cortex is allowed to work out which body parts have to move and how to achieve it. Over two hundred studies have confirmed that athletes perform better and learn faster with external focus (even if they marked on the pre-experiment questionnaire that they prefer an internal focus).

The exercise with the taped box may appear simple or unrelated to bachata. And that’s a good thing if it’s simple and easy to pick up the movements. I’ve observed that students who learn the traditional way tend to struggle to remember with which foot to step, have difficulty with timing, and start stepping in bizarre ways. Students learning the taped box exercise first tend to effortlessly pickup and basic steps in minutes.


OPTION---
This exercise comes from agility training with ladders. You may practice the actual bachata steps right after doing the box version to transfer the learned movement to bachata. To avoid repeating the instruction, the bachata version for each step is in its own mini-lesson.

lessons.title: Basic In Place
lessons.synopsis: One of the fundamental basic patterns.
lessons.instructions:
0. Put your weight on your right leg. Tap your left leg. (See below for proper tapping.)
1. Step on the left leg.
2. Step on the right leg.
3. Step on the left leg.
4. Tap with the right leg.
5. Step on the right leg.
6. Step on the left leg.
7. Step on the right leg.
8. Tap with the left leg.
9. Repeat a few times going faster each time.
10. Put on a slow song and repeat to the song.


MOTIVATION---
The basic in place is one of the common basics. It tends to be tricky for students because there is no movement and they get lost on which foot to step one. If students develop a clear mechanic to always transfer their weight right away and fully on each step, it becomes easier.


HOW TO TAP PROPERLY---
Many students seemingly refuse to tap for inexplicable reasons and do all kinds of other things or nothing at all. A tapped foot has no weight on it. Thus, it is free to step on the next beat. The tapped foot is right next to the weighted foot. The balls of the tapped foot are in the middle of the weighted foot.


TIP---
Students often get confused on which foot to step next with. This can easily be prevented by focusing on putting the complete weight on each foot that steps right away. That way, there is always one foot that has weight and one foot that doesn’t. The foot that has no weight is logically the next foot to step with.

Quite a few students step very messily. There is no telling between when their feet are apart and together. There is no telling between which foot should have weight and which one shouldn’t. Perhaps, they are afraid of making a mistake and hedge their bets by doing something halfway in between. However, it becomes really confusing for them on what to do next. Plus, if a follower were to try to follow them, it’s very confusing to what’s going on.

Step clearly on when the feet are together and apart. Put the weight on one foot. Everything will become easier.


STYLING---
Of course, it goes without saying that you want to do all the basics of this level with the body movement technique of the previous level: hip movements, keep the shoulders at the same level, etc.

Additionally, there is specific styling for the basic in place. Once you have the step pattern down and applied the basic body movement technique, you can add the following. As you travel to the left, you want to slightly turn your body to the left. (Many students take that as turning a full 90 degrees. However, it’s only meant to add a little flavor - like 20-30 degrees - not be an actual turn!)

Also for most of the basic, the knees are typically bent to allow more hip movement. However, on the tap on each side, it’s a nice styling attribute to raise up a bit. (Sometimes, it makes sense to lower a bit more down on the tap. For example, when the music has a heavy drop on the 4 and 8, a physical drop might make more sense than rising up.)

lessons.title: Forward/Backward Basic
lessons.synopsis: Another fundamental basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start by tapping on the left.
1. Step forward with the left foot.
2. Step forward with the right foot.
3. Step forward with the left foot.
4. Tap with the right foot.
5. Step back with the right foot.
6. Step back with the left foot.
7. Step back with the right foot.
8. Tap with the left foot.
9. Repeat a few times, getting faster each time.
10. Put on a slow song and repeat.


STEPPING TOGETHER OR PASSING---
The forward/backward basic is often taught in two variations. Some instructors teach that the middle step should be the feet stepping next to each other. The reasoning is that (almost) all basic steps have the pattern of stepping the feet together on 2. Other instructors teach that the feet should be traveling past each other like a natural walk. Their reasoning is that it’s more important for the chest to smoothly travel forward, which is easier that way. (They try to avoid a move-stop-move pattern that stepping together might create.) While some argue, some suggest that it’s a styling choice.


STYLING---
One way to do the forward/backward basic is to move with square shoulders. A common styling option is to lead with the right shoulder in the direction of travel (e.g. the right shoulder is forward when stepping forward. Thus the body is tilted to the left.).

Another common styling option is to replace the step on the side on 4 with crossing the right foot behind the left and tapping the tip of the toes on the floor.

lessons.title: Lateral Basic
lessons.synopsis: Another fundamental basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start with your weight on the right leg and the left foot tapped.
1. Step left with the left leg. (Be sure to commit weight and not simply flare.)
2. Shift your weight back onto the right leg. (Students often forget to count this because there is no step and simply a weight shift.
3. Step the left leg back to the right leg.
4. Tap wit the right foot.
5-8. Repeat on the other side.
9. Repeat starting slowly and getting faster each time.
10. Put on a slow song and repeat.


TECHNIQUE---
The outward step is often done poorly by students. They don’t put weight on it. They simply flare the foot out quickly. So many teachers say to make the outward step a full step. That goes into the right direction.

However, Korke teaches that the upper body shouldn’t travel with the foot outwards. I think of it like faking a step in basketball. You try to make your opponent believe that you are going in one direction by fully stepping there. However, as your foot lands, you are prepared to bounce back in the other direction. So you get your full weight on the foot not because your body is over the foot but from a combination of the bounce back and the body partially having traveled to that side. Stylistically, the bounce back allows you to to a full weight transfer and it allows you to do a nice hip swing in the direction.

(Note: A bounce back doesn’t mean speeding up and doing a “blitz” movement like in basketball. You have to carefully time your body to stay with the speed of the music but still bounce back.)


VARIATIONS---
The lateral basic has a number of variations that are fun and valuable to practice. You can easily spend a lot of time working on this.

- CROSSING IN FRONT/BEHIND: The 3 and 7 step that usually brings out outside foot back to the other foot can do a number of interesting alternatives. One alternative is on 3 or 7 to step in front of the other foot. The same is possible by stepping behind.

- CROSS IN FRONT - HEEL TO TOE: A variation of crossing in front is to cross in front 3 but to only place the left heel down. Then on 4, step the whole left foot flat and skip the tap. Repeat similarly on 7.

- CROSS IN FRONT - CHA-CHA: Another variation is to cross in front on 3. Shift the weight back on the right foot on “and.” Shift the weight back on the left foot on 4. (Skip the tap.) The “and” count is something that we’ll get into later when learning about musicality and syncopations. The “and” count is half a beat. It’s the measure between two beats.

lessons.title: Box Step/Quadrato
lessons.synopsis: Another fundamental basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start with your weight on the right foot and the left foot tapped.
1. Step left with the left foot.
2. Step your right foot to your left foot. (Remember to commit your weight at the end of each step or you’ll get confused here!)
3. Step forward with the left foot.
4. Tap with the right foot.
5. Step right with the right foot.
6. Step your left foot to the right foot.
7. Step back with the right foot.
8. Tap with the left foot.
9. Repeat starting slowly and getting faster each time.
10. Put on a slow song and repeat.


VARIATIONS---
(The above version is the most common version and the first version taught. The following versions are less common. Some of them may not be seen at all in certain circles.)

 - START ON 1 OR 5: The box step can be started on 1 or 5. If you start on 5, everything is mirrored. (E.g. the first step is to the right.)

- START TO THE SIDE OR FORWARD: Instead of starting to the side, one can also start forward. Accordingly, the steps are changed, but the pattern of step - together - step - tap remains the same.

- SLIDE: Stepping to the side on 1 remains the same. The step on 2 however becomes a compound slide. Within one beat, the right foot slides to meet the left foot and shoots forward to land where the forward step would land. On 3, the left foot steps to meet the right. On 4, there is a tap. The step repeats similarly on the other side with a slide.

- ELONGATED OR ENERGETIC BOX: The box starts as usual on 1. On 2, the above-described slide happens. The difference is on 3. On 3, the left foot doesn’t step to the right foot but steps forward. On 4, the right foot has to move forward to meet the left for the tap. This pattern looks more like an L than a square box.


STYLING---
- CROSS BEHIND: Almost as common as doing the plain box is to step the right foot behind the left foot on 2. It creates a nice tilt to the right on the body. (Note that this is a tilt not a full-on turn.)

- CROSS IN FRONT: Similarly, on 6, the left foot can cross in front of the right foot.

- CHA-CHA: When stepping forward and backward, a cha-cha can be inserted. This would be two syncopated steps: 1 - 2 - and - 3 - and - tap. A level later will teach musicality and syncopations. This is listed here for completeness.

lessons.title: Madrid Step/Diagonales
lessons.synopsis: Another fundamental basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
(The key to understanding this step is that all basics until this one have been either going side-to-side or back-and-forth. However, this step travels in a diagonal direction: back-left to front-right.)

0. Start with your weight on the right leg and the left foot tapped.
1. Step the left foot back and to the left. Swivel your knees to the front-left corner of the room.
2. Shift your weight back to the right foot. (Not step!) Swivel your knees to the front-right corner of the room.
3. Step the left foot across the right foot and travel forward and to the right.
4. Tap your left foot and face your knees to the front.
5. Step your right foot forward and to the right. Swivel the knees to the front-left corner of the room.
6. Shift your weight back to the left foot. (No step!) Swivel your knees to the front-right corner of the room.
7. Step the right foot behind the left foot to travel to your starting point.
8. Tap your left foot. Straighten your knees out to the front.
9. Repeat starting slowly and getting faster each time.
10. Put on a slow song and repeat.


SWIVELING PATTERN---
Students tend to get confused about the swiveling pattern because there are so many steps in different directions and swivels going on. Here is a mental organizing pattern that’ll make it easy to remember what to do.

All the swivels are alternating. So you know if you swiveled one way recently, you are going to swivel the next way soon.

The trick then becomes remembering which way to swivel first to get started right. That’s pretty easy to remember with a little logic. Do the the first opening step. Try swiveling to the left. You’ll notice your knees crossing as if you have to pee badly. This is obviously not the right way. Swiveling your knees to the left feels a lot easier.


CHEST TURN OR NOT---
Some teachers teach that the chest should always face forward. The knees/hips should disassociate for the swivels.

Other teachers suggest that the above is done as an “over-correction.” Students tend to completely turn to the side, which is wrong. So telling them to face forward is an easy way to fix that problem. However, these other teachers suggest that the chest should somewhat turn because otherwise, the follower wouldn’t have any signal to do the swivels herself. Thus, the proper amount of turning is enough so that the lead transmits to the follower, but not so much as to disconnect from the follower and face somewhere else.


NAMING---
Madrid step is a common name for this pattern. I’ve heard second hand that Daniel y Desire do not like the name because it wasn’t the original name and the step originated nowhere near Madrid. Korke calls this step "Diagonales" because he likes to emphasize that the main aspect is that the step is diagonal. And any variation that’s diagonal falls under this pattern.


VARIATIONS---
- HIP SWING INSTEAD OF SWIVELS: A variation is to do big traditional hip swings instead of swivels.

- SLIDES: Another variation is to skip the tap and to slide through. The 3 and 7 step become elongated to consume the count of the tap.

- HEAD TURN: Not so much for shines but when partner dancing, leading the follower to look over her right shoulder when she steps back and to her left is a frequent and fun touch.


USEFULNESS FOR FIGURES---
You might want to take particular note of the Madrid step to use it as a prep for partnered dancing. Because the step has a turning momentum in it, it lends itself nicely as a prep for various figures. For example, it can provide the initial momentum for a head roll. Often only half of the Madrid step is used to prep into something else.

lessons.title: Grapevine
lessons.synopsis: Another fundamental basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start with your weight on your right foot. Your left foot is tapped.
1. Cross your left foot in front of your right foot. (Note: You are traveling to the right in this basic.)
2. Step your right foot to the side.
3. Step your left foot behind the right foot.
4. Flare your right foot out. (See below for how to flare.)
5. Cross your right foot behind your left foot.
6. Step your left foot to the side.
7. Cross your right foot in front of your left foot.
8. Flare the left foot out.

Note: Angle your chest with the direction changes as you would for the Madrid step.


HOW TO FLARE---
This pattern doesn’t tap but flare. A flare is also unweighted like a tap. However, instead of being next to the other foot, the flared foot is shot out to the side with a straight leg. The flared should be pointed.

Many students initially struggle with how much the flared leg should be rotated. You don’t want to rotate it out so that the sole of your shoe shows. You don’t want to rotate it in so that the leg looks awkward and pigeon-toed. There is a pretty degree of rotation where the leg is nicely elongated and the “pretty” part shows to the audience.


HOW TO EXIT---
Because this basic flares instead of taps, it’s a little tricky to exit the pattern. The rule is that if you want to continue doing grapevines, flare on 8. If you want to exit the grapevines, tap on 8.


VARIATIONS---
The most typical crossing pattern is to do front, back, back, and front. However, you can switch up the front and back or to only do front however you want. Mathematically, there are 16 possible versions.


USEFULNESS FOR FIGURES---
The grapevine is perhaps the least likely basic pattern that a dance partner at a social knows. As such, it doesn’t happen often. However, it can provide a very eye-catching and performance-like way to travel together over distance.

lessons.title: Open Break
lessons.synopsis: A key step pattern for later figures.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start with your weight on your right foot. Your left foot is tapped.
1. Step forward with the left foot.
2. Shift the weight back onto the right foot. (No step!)
3. Step the left foot back to the original place.
4. Tap on the right.
5. Step the right foot back.
6. Shift the weight back onto the left foot. (No step!)
7. Step the right foot back to the original place.
8. Tap with the left foot.


SHUFFLE ALTERNATIVE---
A step that’s often taught as a different step, but is similar and serves the same function in partner dance doesn’t seem to have a name. I’ve heard one instructor refer to it as a shuffle.

The open break is essentially a step forward and back. The shuffle alternative steps both feet forward.

On 2 and 6 instead of simply shifting the weight back, the foot that was left behind steps to meet the other foot.

1. Step forward left.
2. Step forward right.
3. Step back left.
4. Tap right.
5. Step back right.
6. Step back left.
7. Step forward right.
8. Tap left.


OPEN BREAK WITH A 90-DEGREE TURN---
A way to dress up the open break is to add a 90-degree turn.

1. Step forward left.
2. Shift the weight back to the right.
3. As the left foot travels back, travel past the right foot so that the left foot induces a turn to the left by 90 degrees.
4. When the left foot taps, rotate the foot to face to the left.
5. Step backward with the right foot.
6. Shift the weight back to the left and turn the left foot to face forward.
7. Step the right foot back to meet the left foot in the starting position.
8. Tap on the left.


USEFULNESS FOR FIGURES---
The open break is a bread-and-butter step that you’ll frequently use for partner figures. It’s the most common way to initiate entering shadow position. Doing the shuffle step is a way to dress up these common patterns with something a bit more challenging and uncommon.

lessons.title: Basics Shines Practice
lessons.synopsis: Training the recall of the basic patterns.
lessons.instructions:
There is no new information for this lesson. This lesson practices recalling the basic step patterns while dancing to the music. The instructor will call out the next pattern. And when the "1" starts, everyone will do the next pattern. (Usually, every lesson has a practice video. However, it’s important to elevate this recall training as a lesson itself.)


INFORMAL HAND SIGNALS---
With the music going loud enough to feel it, it can be hard to hear the instructor. I came up with these informal hand signals to announce the next type of basic. These are by no means standardized. However, they are relatively intuitive. Most instructors develop a similar hand signal vocabulary.

- ARM POINTING TO THE LEFT: Regular basic
- BOTH ARMS POINTING FORWARD: Forward basic
- BOTH THUMBS POINTING BACKWARD: Backward basic
- BOTH ARMS POINTING STRAIGHT DOWN: Basic in place
- BOTH ARMS POINTING OUT AND DOWN AT AN ANGLE: Lateral basic
- LEFT ARM POINTING LEFT AND BACK: Madrid step

lessons.title: Push’n’Pull Grip
lessons.synopsis: The first of many hand connections.
lessons.instructions:
1. Find the push-n-pull grip with a partner. (See below)
2. Do the weight exercise with a partner. (See below)
3. Do the walking exercise with a partner. (See below)


PUSH’N’PULL GRIP---
The leader presents his hands a little above the hip level. The palms are facing forward. The hand is angled out so that the top of the index finger and the inside edge of the palm provide a horizontal surface.

The follower places her hands over the above horizontal surface. Her wrist breaks so that both of the palms are pressing against each other. For both partners, it’s important to connect the base of the palms. Otherwise, the lead signals will transmit delayed or not at all! To achieve this, it might require rotating the hands a bit more out.

The amount of space between the body and elbow should avoid either extreme: The elbows shouldn’t be on the body. The elbows shouldn’t be high like for ballroom dancing. There should be comfortable space but also comfortable to hold for a long time.

The angle of the forearm tends to also cause problems for students. There is no simplistic recipe. To get the right angle, consider the purpose. The purpose is for the leader to control the follower’s hips. That the leader’s forearms should be angled towards her hips. (There is a variation where the leader’s forearms are angled towards her shoulder. As you’d expect that variation is done to control her shoulders.)


COMMON PROBLEMS---
- CONNECT AT THE BASE OF THE PALM - NO TENTING! Virtually every beginner will leave space at the base of the palms so that the follower and leader create a tent. If the leader were to step forward, the space would have to fill first before the follower receives the momentum. Thus, she would be late. It’s not simply style but a critical function that the heels of the palm are connected.

- NO GRIPPING! A lot of students will grip the other person’s hand. This is not only unnecessary but can also become pretty uncomfortable as the other person’s hand is squeezed too hard. It’s possible and completely fine to use this grip with the fingers completely open. Both partners should be providing pressure against each other. And if the leader wants to lead the follower’s hand forward, he simply needs to pull back and the follower should maintain the pressure.

- SPAGHETTI ARMS! A lot of students will have soft arms. So if a leader moves forward, the follower absorb all the momentum with her arms and stays in place. You want to imagine that you have a broom stick stuck between your elbows and belly. Thus if the leader were to push on your hands, the hand pressure directly translates to your torso moving back.

- LEADING WITH THE HANDS INSTEAD OF THE FRAME! Beginning leaders often move with the arms instead of the frame. That is they want the follower to step back and push with their arms. The proper way to do it is to use the frame. With frame, we mean that the arms stay in place and move together with the torso as a unit. Equally to the follower, the leader should think of having a broom stick pinned between the elbows and belly. Thus the leader cannot extend or pullback the arms. One reason for this is that the arms have very little weight. They can move very fast. The body has more weight and more inertia. Thus to move a body smoothly, you want to move it in sync with your own body to match the inertia and momentum of the follower.


WEIGHT EXERCISE---
Start with your partner in push’n’pull grip. Then walk your feet a few inches away from each other while maintaining the grip and arm position. This should cause both of your to lean forward at an angle. You’ll feel that you’ll fall if your partner wouldn’t push back on you. That’s the necessary feeling that the exercise goes for. If you cheat and keep your weight balanced on your own feet, you won’t be doing the exercise.

Often the weight between the partners is different. You’ll notice that the lighter partner has to lean more forward to maintain an equilibrium.

Slowly squat down (while maintaining the forward lean). You’ll realize that you have to negotiate with your partner to equally lean against each other or you both lose your balance. That’s the goal of this exercise: Learn to meet pressure with equal pressure. Maintain constant pressure as you go through movement.

Repeat the squatting. Increase the challenge level by stepping farther away from each other to increase the dependence and pressure that you have to negotiate.


WALKING EXERCISE---
Start with your partner in push’n’pull grip. The leader decides a random moment to either step forward or backward. If the leader maintains the frame and the follower has no spaghetti arms, the leader and follower should move together in sync. Also tenting at the palms can cause issues.

The leader keeps switching between moving forward, backward, paushing, and changing the speed. The leader and follower learn to maintain their frame and constant pressure on the hand connection.

lessons.title: Bolero
lessons.synopsis: An important lead signal to prepare the follower.
lessons.instructions:
The bolero is somewhat difficult to practice in isolation. For this lesson, you’ll try it out with a partner to the best of your ability. We’ll discuss what it is. And in the next lessons, you’ll get to actually practice it in the context of dancing.


WHAT IT IS---
The bolero is a lead signal to the follower that something different is about to happen. Most easily, it is described as a deep inhale and rising up. Imagine that you stand in front of your boss’s office and are about to read him/her the riot act. You may take a moment to work up the courage. But when you are ready, you might take a deep inhale, rise up, and then launch forward to burst through his/her door. Energetically, that’s what you are looking for.

Bachata is most of the time danced with bend knees. So rising up to straight legs should be noticable as well as raising the chest with the inhale. You don’t want to go up on your tippy toes or raise your shoulders.


WHEN TO USE IT---
By default, both partners dance the regular bachata side-to-side. There is no signal needed for that to repeat until the song ends. However, if we want to switch to the forward basic, we need to give the follower a heads-up. So as we draw the left foot to meet the right foot for the tap on 8, we’d do a bolero. The follower will notice that something is up and be prepared to watch out for the next lead signal on what to do.

Similarly, if we want to enter the box step, we’d do a bolero as we arrive on 2. (It wouldn’t make sense to signal the box step on 1 because we start like a regular basic. Only when we diverge from the regular basic for the follower to step back do we need to signal with a bolero.)


HOW TO BE CLEAR OR HOW TO BE LOUD WITHOUT BEING LOUD---
This is a discussion of an important aspect of leading. Students will often try to make the bolero noticeable by standing on their tippy toes or raising their shoulders. That’s not desirable, but how does one make the bolero clear?

Like a lot of lead signals, their success depends not on the signal itself but the context. If you have a very quiet lead, every signal will stand out clearly even if it is pretty small. What is a quiet lead? Remember how the regular basic was introduced and swinging the arms was discouraged? A lot of movements, especially random movements, created noise. If your body is still and you maintain the same chest level consistently, your follower will pick up any changes clearly. So the answer is not in making the signal louder but eliminating all the noise that the other movements create.

A finer topic to talk about is that there is a difference between no movement and consistent movement. Quiet as in no movement is one way to make a signal stand out. The other is to create movement patterns. Imagine that you are tapping your pen at a very consistent pace for a while. If you then make a small extra tap, people will notice. The more consistent and precise your movement patterns are, the more consistent and precise any derivation stands out.

If you are wondering how to be quiet and consistent? Look back at the movement technique lessons. Often beginner students try to rush past them to do “cool” things. Yet once they try the cool things and they don’t work so well, they get an appreciation from it for working on the basic movement technique. This focus on movement technique tends to only increase as dancers advance.

lessons.title: Dancing the Six Basics With A Partner
lessons.synopsis: Integrating all the basics, push'n'pull grip, and bolero to dance with a partner to music.
lessons.instructions:
This is another integration lesson that doesn’t introduce new material. This lesson pulls together the basic steps, push-n-pull grip, and bolero. You want to dance with a partner. Your partner will lead the different basic patterns and use the push-n-pull grip with boleros to signals the follower what’s next.

In contrast to choreography classes, giving the leader a choice of figures requires the leader to learn actual leading skills and the follower following skills. The leader will also learn to develop choreographies on the spot.


To progress this exercise, start with doing a regular basic and then one other basic. The regular basic in between provides the mind a little break to recover focus and prepare for the next basic. Once that works well, go from one type of basic to the next. After that, do half a basic of one kind and then half a basic of another kind. Say do the first four counts as the box step but finish the last four counts with a basic in place.

lessons.title: Spin And Spot
lessons.synopsis: Fundamental technique for turns and spins.
lessons.instructions:
(These are successive drills to develop your turns. Spend as much time as you want on each drill and keep going back to it.)

1. Assume the starting position: Stand on one leg. Point the other leg out to the side as far as naturally goes. Raise your arms so that they move a ninety degree angle. Move your arms as far away as possible from your standing leg.

2. Do ninety-degree turns: Accelerate your arms horizontally towards your standing leg. Suddenly, arrest the arm movement. This should transmit the movement to your whole body and induce a spin. The goal of the drill is to dose your momentum to create ninety-degree turns as precisely as possible.

3. Control momentum with the leg: The progression of the exercise takes advantage of a physics principle. Mass far away from the center of rotation creates more inertia than mass close. As you spin, tug your free foot close to your standing foot. The heels should be touching. As you stop, should your free foot back out. You should feel your momentum accelerating as you move the free foot in and slowing as you move the free foot back out.

4. Repeat with 180-degree turns: Progress the drill from ninety-degree to 180 degrees. This will require you to generate more momentum. It will also require more precision to land it exactly.

5. Repeat with 360-degree turns: Progress the drill to 360-degree turns. This should be a significant challenge to land them precisely without wobble. Expect to spend days practicing this skill.

6. Repeat with spotting: Spotting is a technique the prevents getting dizzy while turning. You will pick a spot on the wall in front of your at eye level. As your body turns, you’ll keep your face towards the spot. When you reach the end of your ability to rotate your neck, you’ll keep your eyes facing the spot. When your eyes are all the way in the corner and your neck is all the way turned, your body will likely be close to 180 degrees opposite to your start. At this point, snap your head around as quickly as possible to look at the spot from the other corner of your eye. As your body catches up to where your face faces, you’ll neck rotation will unwind and the eyes will look straight ahead.

7. Go through the previous progressions using the other leg and turning the other way. (There are four possible combinations to turn!)

8. Now that you have some experience turning your body, we have to transform the turn where we don’t use the arms. (Our partner would be in the way of those wide, held-out arms.) So we lower our arms. To generate momentum, we are going to rotate our hips and arrest that movement. Because the hips are much closer to the center of rotation, they have less power and require more finesse. Go through the drill steps again, using your hips instead of your arms.

Motivation---
Every yokel can go to a wedding, raise an arm and the partner will attempt some kind of turning motion. While that yokel may derive a lot of pleasure and pride from “having completely mastered dancing,” there is a lot of technique to turning. If you want your partner to end in a useful position, the steps have to be precise and not a mangled mess with unexpected landing spot. Turns are one of the pillars of beauty in dance. There is a lot to it. This entire level is dedicated to turning. This lesson sets the foundation.


Being a little kit and skating on the frozen sidewalk---
A lot of students struggle with using the arms to generate the turn momentum. They will move the arms but not suddenly arrest them. Most of us have learned the principle behind the sudden arrest as kids. Little kids like to run on a frozen sidewalk. And when the take a sudden wide stance without running, they start sliding across the ice. We use the same technique to do the turns on a dancefloor.


Tip---
Students come with all kinds of shoes to class. If you have proper dance shoes, you are probably doing okay. If you wear sneakers with rubber soles, they probably won’t allow you to spin. The worst part is that they’ll create a lot of stress on your knees and might lead to injury. For this drill, taking shoes off and using socks is probably going to make it easiest to spin. You might want to roll your socks down half of your foot. That way, your heel is bare and gives you some hold to avoid falling. Yet when you want to turn, you can stand on the balls of your free, which are sock covered, to have the most freedom to spin.

lessons.title: Step Pattern Inside Turn
lessons.synopsis: The bread and butter bachata turn.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start in the typical start position: Weight on the right foot and left foot tapped.
1. Step the left foot to the left and rotate the foot ninety degrees to point left.
2. Pivot on the left foot and step the right foot into the direction of travel. You should face the back of the room.
3. Pivot on the right foot and step the left foot farther into the direction of travel. You should face the fotn of the room.
4. Tap the right foot.

Note: The turn can also be started on 5 instead of on 1. Then the steps are mirrored.


Motivation---
The inside turn is the bread and butter of bachata turns. It’s the most common turn. During a song, you’ll likely do it a dozen times.


Common Problems---
- GET LOST ON THE FOOTWORK: The second step tends to cause students the most problems. The first step is quite clear, but the second step confuses them because they partially turned. The solution is quite simple. Each time you step, commit the weight right away. That way, you’ll have only one foot free to moe. And that’s the next foot to use.

- GET LOST ON THE TURN DIRECTION: Even though, the turn goes in the same direction with each step, some students get confused on the direction and start going the other way suddenly. The problem is that these students take each step, pause, and then think about what to do next. A cue that tends to help is to look at your watch. If it’s on your right wrist, you’ll want to always lead the turn with the watch.

- SPINNING IN PLACE: Some students will spin in place and then add some steps. However, this is a traveling turn. With every step, you want to turn a bit more.

- NOT TRAVELING: Some students do the steps, but they do them all in place. The steps should be space the same as doing a basic. The reason is that the partner will be doing a basic. So our bodies should travel together to the side - even though one person turns and the other person doesn’t.


Inside vs. Outside---
As the name inside turn suggests, there is also an outside turn. Inside refers to the space between the couple. In this turn, as we are turning in the travel of dance, we are turning inside. In the next lesson, we’ll turn to the right as we travel left. That’ll lead us to face the outside and will be the outside turn.

lessons.title: Step Pattern Outside Turn
lessons.synopsis: The step sibling of the inside turn.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start in the default start position: Left foot tapped and weight on the right foot.
1. Step the left foot to the left. Aim the heel to face ninety degrees to the left. (Both your knees will be turned in and you’ll start facing to the right.)
2. Step the right foot to the right of the left foot. Face the back of the room.
3. Step the left foot so that you face the front of the room again.
4. Tap.

Note: The steps can also be started on 5 instead of on 1. The step would be mirrored.


Notes---
The outside turn is similar to the inside turn. However, it’s generally less familiar to people to turn that way. And the first step is rather awkward for many people. So, it takes more practice.

lessons.title: Step Pattern Quick Turn
lessons.synopsis: Energetic turns for spice.
lessons.instructions:
Quick turn on 1:
0. Start in the default position: The left foot is tapped, and the weight is on the right foot.
1. With the left foot, step left, and spin 360 degrees.
2. With the right foot, step together.
3. With the left foot, step left.
4. Tap with the right foot.

Quick turn on 3:
0. Start in the default position: The left foot is tapped, and the weight is on the right foot.
1. With the left foot, step left.
2. With the right foot, step together.
3. With the left foot, step left, and spin 360 degrees.
4. Tap with the right foot.


Motivation---
Because quick turns are essentially spins on one beat and ladning on the second beat, they are very short and fit into other figures. It’s less common to do them on their own.


Variations---
As the instructions show, quick turns can be initiated on 1 and 3. Of course, they can also be initiated on the second half of the basic (on 5 and 7 respectively). Another option is to do outside quick turns instead of inside quick turns. Quick turns can also be combined, e.g. an inside quick turn on 1 and 3.


How To Lead The Different Turns---
This is a little preview for when we get to leading turns. An obvious question is: How does one lead the different turns? How does the follower know which turn to execute. The lead for an inside versus quick turn are the same form. However, a quick turn gives the follower more momentum. Turns can be done at different speeds. A turn could even be slowed down to take eight counts. In that case, the lead would have to give very little momentum.

lessons.title: Step Pattern Prep Turn
lessons.synopsis: A fun, explosive turn.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start in the default position: The left foot is tapped, and the weight is on the right foot.
1. Step left with the left foot. This step should include a slight rotation into the opposite direction of the intended turn.
2. Shift the weight back to the right foot.
3. Turn within one count to the right on the right foot.
4. Tap the right foot.

The key to the execution is that the first step is a winding up to generate massive momentum for the turn.


Motivation---
Prep turns are explosive turns. They try to hit something fast and dramatic in the music. They also tend to lead into something that wants to be landed from big speed.

lessons.title: Step Pattern Delayed Turn
lessons.synopsis: An odd timing turn that can fit in between patterns.
lessons.instructions:
0. Start in the default position: The left foot is tapped, and the weight is on the right foot.
1. First step of a regular basic.
2. Second step of a regular basic.
3. Third step of a regular basic.
4. Instead of tapping, do a 180-degree turn and flare the right leg out.
5. Complete a second 180-degree turn and step the right foot as you would do the fifth step of a regular basic.
6-8. Complete the regular basic.

Variation: The delayed turn can also be done between 8 and 1.


Usefullness For Figures---
A lot of figures happen between 1 and 4 as well as between 5 and 8. The noteworthy part of the delayed turn is that it happens in the gaps that these typical hotspots create. Thus, the delayed turn can easily be added in between figures.

For example, the leader leads a regular inside turn for the follower from 5 to 8. As the follower only has to tap on 8, the leader is free to do a delayed leader turn on 8 and finish on 1 for the next thing to start. This kind of leader turn is often combined with keeping a followers hand on the shoulder and doing a neck roll under the follower’s hand.

Related are also maneuvers like the mosquetero. That’s often danced where the follower does an inside turn that ends with an overrotation so that both the leader and follower look to the right. From here, the leader can lead both the follower and himself to do a kind of delayed turn.

The creativity of the delayed turn lies into using it after another figure to create something more interesting.

levels.description: A bonus choreography created for bachata in the park.

lessons.title: Basic With Timing
lessons.instructions:
1. 3 steps to the left plus a tap; 3 steps to the right plus a tap.
2. Start dancing on "1" in the music. Start and stop to practice finding the "1".


Tips:---
- The "1" is the beat with the most emphasis.
- The "4" and "5" have a flat sound to them.
- If you are unsure about the music, instead of simply standing, do a side-tap-side-tap step to feel the music.

lessons.title: Chest-Led Basic
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead the basic with the chest (in the direction of the stepping foot).
2. The hip will naturally pop out to the other side.
3. When tapping, move the chest to the same side as before.

Tips:---
- Bend your knees to allow your hips more movement.
- Complex movements overwhelm the brain. Find a focal point and let the rest of the body move as a consequence. Here we exercise putting our focus on the chest movement and letting the rest happen as a consequence.

lessons.title: Four-Step Turn
lessons.instructions:
(For a turn starting on 5 after half a basic.)

5. Step 90 degrees into the turn.
6. Step facing away from your partner.
7. Step back to face your partner.
8. Tap.

Leading instructions:---
3. Prep the turn by moving the outside hand up.
4. Turn your partner slightly away from the turn.
5. Drop the leading hand down as soon as it clears the follower's head.
6. Signal the end of the turn with the hand low.

Hand/Arm Position:---
- Begin with turn-pattern grip: Only connected as the fingers. The fingers are slightly curved to "hook."
- At the start of the turn the follower’s elbow is down and the leader’s is up.
- The leader’s hand is at the level of the follower’s eyes and traces in a tight halo, almost touching her hair.

lessons.title: Overturn Into Side-By-Side With A Comb
lessons.instructions:
Instructions:---
1. Execute mostly like a normal four-step turn.
2. At the end, the lead should pull stronger with the right hand to turn the follower an extra 90 degrees.
3. On "8", the leader pushes his right arm out to the right so that her right arm is straight across his chest.
4. The leader’s left arm should lift up to lock the follower’s right arm across the leaders chest. This is a block.
5. The leader can now do a comb by moving the hand backwards with the left hand.

Tips:
- The leader’s side of the chest against the follower, the stretched follower’s right arm, and the crook of the leader’s left arm should create a firm lock.
- The sequence of the move should be lock first with the right arm. Then the left arm moves as "surprise" to comb.

lessons.title: Body Roll Moving Backwards
lessons.instructions:
(Anatomy of a body wave)
0. Prep by puffing out the chest and moving up. The weight is on the front leg.
1. Roll the shoulders only back.
2. Concave the the chest in.
3. Concave the abs in.
4. Swing the hips back like a pendulum. The weight should be on the back leg.

Instructions:---
(Step pattern)
1. Start the wave and shoot your leg back.
2. Finish the wave and transfer your weight back.
3. Start a second wave and shoot your leg back.
4. Finish the second wave.

Tips:---
- Body movements are generally led by the lead doing the movement and the follower being connected to the body. The lock that we end in previously creates a good connection point.

- Body waves are often taught in two ways: (1) The movement is taught slowly and explicitly by going through each phase. (2) The movement is taught by going through it and picturing oneself like a seaweed that’s rippled by the current. Try both approaches.

lessons.title: Side Wave Into Quick Turn
lessons.instructions:
4. At the end of the last four count, start by prepping the chest to the left.
5. Step to the right and do a side body wave to the right. The follower steps with the right foot in front of the lead.
6. Do a side body wave to the left. (No steps only weight shift).
7. Do a quick right turn for the follower. (Leader leads with the right hand.)
8. Tap

Alternative:---
Instead of stepping in 5, a smaller side wave can be made without stepping.

Different types of waves:---
Doing a full body wave on 4 counts is the default. However, body waves can be done on different times: slower (8 counts or faster 1 or 2 counts). Body waves can also be full body waves or only the chest wave without the hip swing. In this case, we are doing small, chest-focused body waves on 1 count.

Quick turns:---
In contrast to the four-step turn from earlier, this is a quick turn. The whole turn (spin in this case) happens on a single count. Quick turns are often prepped with a step in the opposite direction (called "prep turns"). In this case, we have a quick turn and prep it with a body wave in the opposite direction.
